The question asks for the difference in the number of people over 65 years old who do not trust information from the World Health Organization (WHO) compared to postgraduates who do not trust information from the European Union (EU) regarding the coronavirus outbreak.

From the text quotes, we find that "half of people with a high school degree say they trust information from this source" [4], and "about three-quarters of Americans with a postgraduate degree (78%) or college degree (72%) say they can believe information coming from the EU about the coronavirus outbreak" [6]. This suggests that postgraduates have a higher level of trust in the EU compared to high school graduates. However, we need specific data on the number of people over 65 who do not trust the WHO.

Looking at the image quotes, image2 provides detailed data on trust levels across different demographics. For the WHO, the data for people over 65 (ages 65+) is as follows: Not at all: 26%, Not too much: 23%, A fair amount: 34%, and A great deal: 16%. The percentage who do not trust the WHO (Not at all + Not too much) is 26% + 23% = 49%.

For postgraduates, the data from image2 shows: Not at all: 14%, Not too much: 15%, A fair amount: 39%, and A great deal: 31%. The percentage who do not trust the EU (Not at all + Not too much) is 14% + 15% = 29%.

Thus, the difference in the percentage of people over 65 who do not trust the WHO compared to postgraduates who do not trust the EU is 49% - 29% = 20%. 

![{The image shows the percentage of people who do not trust the WHO and the EU based on age and education level.}]![{The image shows the percentage of people who do not trust the WHO and the EU based on age and education level.}](image2)

20% more people over 65 years old do not trust information from the World Health Organization compared to postgraduates who do not trust information from the European Union in regard to the coronavirus outbreak.

From 2008 to 2016, the political orientations of Republican and Democratic voters have shown distinct shifts. In 2008, a majority of Republican voters (59%) believed GOP leaders should work with Obama, while in 2016, this number dropped significantly, reflecting a more conservative stance. ![Republican Party (Rep Party)](image2) This is evident in the data showing that 60% of Republican and Republican-leaning voters wanted the party to move in a more conservative direction in 2016, compared to 57% in 2012 and 59% in 2008 [7]. 

For Democrats, the trend is more nuanced. In 2008, 57% of Democratic voters favored a more moderate direction, but by 2016, this had shifted, with 49% wanting a more liberal stance and 47% favoring moderation [9]. ![More moderate vs More liberal](image3) The chart shows a narrowing gap between "More moderate" and "More liberal" by 2016, indicating a shift towards more liberal views among Democrats.

The image also highlights the contrast in voter satisfaction. In 2016, a significant portion of voters were unhappy, with 45% of all voters feeling unhappy, while Trump voters were predominantly happy (94%) and Clinton voters were mostly unhappy (87%) [1]. This reflects the polarized political climate and the differing perceptions of the election outcomes.

Based on the provided text and image quotes, we can analyze how voter opinions on appointing opposition party members differed between Trump in 2016 and Obama in 2008.

In 2008, after Obama's first victory, 52% of voters who supported him said he should appoint Republicans to his cabinet, which was double the share of Trump backers who favor Democrats in his cabinet today. This indicates that Obama supporters were more likely to support appointing members from the opposing party compared to Trump supporters in 2016.

![Clinton voters should appoint Republicans](image4)

In 2016, only about a quarter (26%) of Trump voters say the president-elect should appoint Democrats to serve in his administration. Twice as many (52%) say it does not matter, while 21% say Trump should not name Democrats to his cabinet. This shows a significant difference in opinion compared to 2008 when Obama voters were more supportive of appointing Republicans.

The data from the image also shows that in 2008, Obama voters were more likely to support appointing Republicans, with 52% saying he should do so, whereas in 2016, Trump voters were less supportive of appointing Democrats, with only 26% saying he should do so.

Therefore, voter opinions on appointing opposition party members differed significantly between Trump in 2016 and Obama in 2008, with Obama supporters being more likely to support appointing members from the opposing party.

The perception of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS showed a notable shift from July to December 2015. In July 2015, 55% of respondents believed the campaign would definitely or probably succeed, while 36% thought it would definitely or probably fail. By December 2015, these numbers had reversed, with 66% believing the campaign would succeed and only 27% expecting failure. This indicates a significant increase in optimism regarding the success of the military effort.

![{The image shows a comparison of bar charts from two different time periods, July 2015 and December 2015. Each period has two bars representing survey results. In July 2015: 36% said "Definitely/Probably fail" and 55% said "Definitely/Probably succeed". In December 2015: 27% said "Definitely/Probably fail" and 66% said "Definitely/Probably succeed". The data indicate an increase in optimism from July to December 2015."](image3)

This change is also reflected in other aspects of public opinion. For instance, the overall rating of how well the U.S. military effort against ISIS was going remained negative, but there was an uptick in the view that the U.S. and its allies would ultimately be successful. Additionally, the percentage of people who viewed ISIS as a major threat to the U.S. increased by 16 points from August 2014, indicating a heightened sense of urgency and concern.

![{The image is a bar chart that compares the percentages of people who rated something "Not too/at all well" versus "Very/Fairly well" over several time periods: Dec 2015, July 2015, Feb 2015, and Oct 2014. The "Not too/at all well" category is represented by the darker golden bars and the percentages are as follows: Dec 2015: 58%, July 2015: 62%, Feb 2015: 58%, Oct 2014: 58%. The "Very/Fairly well" category is represented by the lighter gold bars and the percentages are: Dec 2015: 35%, July 2015: 30%, Feb 2015: 36%, Oct 2014: 34%.}](image4)

Overall, the data suggests that while there were concerns about the effectiveness of the military campaign, there was a growing belief that the U.S. and its allies would eventually succeed in their efforts against ISIS.

The perception of whether Islam encourages violence more than other religions has shown a complex pattern over time, with significant changes across different political affiliations and demographic groups. According to the data, in July 2014, the percentage of Americans who believed Islam was more likely to encourage violence was at a historical high of 50%. By December 2015, this percentage had dropped to 46%, indicating a slight decline [4]. However, this change was not uniform across all groups.

For instance, the share of liberals saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence has decreased by 14 points since the fall of 2014 [3]. On the other hand, the share of Republicans associating Islam with violence has remained relatively stable, with 68% saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence, which is the highest percentage recorded on this question dating back to 2002 [6]. The partisan divide over this issue is now as wide as it has ever been, with 68% of Republicans and 30% of Democrats holding these views [8].

![Islam and Violence Perceptions](image4)  
This image shows how opinions on whether Islam encourages violence more than other religions have changed from 2002 to 2015. The top line represents the percentage of people who believe Islam is no more likely to encourage violence than other religions, starting at 51 in 2002 and ending at 46 in 2015. The bottom line represents the percentage of people who believe Islam is more likely to encourage violence, starting at 25 in 2002 and ending at 45 in 2015.

The data also reveals that there is a significant age gap in these views. For example, 32% of those ages 18 to 29 say Islam encourages violence more than other faiths, compared with roughly half of those in other age groups. However, the age gap in these views is narrower than it was last fall [2]. Additionally, the share of white evangelical Protestants who say Islam encourages violence more than other religions is the highest percentage of any religious group and has remained little changed since 2014 [9].

![Political Affiliations and Religious Scrutiny](image2)  
This image shows the opinions of different political groups on whether individuals should be subject to additional scrutiny solely because of their religion. The data reflects how different political affiliations view religious scrutiny, with Democrats being the most supportive of not subjecting individuals to additional scrutiny based on their religion.

Overall, the data indicates that while there has been a slight decrease in the percentage of Americans who believe Islam encourages violence more than other religions, the partisan divide remains stark, with Republicans being significantly more likely to hold this view than Democrats.

Americans have a mixed perception of the concept of machines performing jobs currently done by humans. According to the data, a majority of Americans are broadly familiar with the notion that automation may impact a wide range of human employment, with 85% having heard or read about this concept before, and 24% indicating they have heard or read "a lot" about it [7]. This is also reflected in the image2, which shows that 24% of Americans have heard a lot about the concept, 61% have heard a little, and 14% have heard nothing at all [2].

The image1 shows that 20% of Americans find the concept of machines doing most human jobs in the future to be extremely realistic, while 57% find it somewhat realistic, and 17% find it not realistic, with 5% finding it not at all realistic [8]. However, another image3 shows that most Americans anticipate significant changes to the nature of jobs and work in the coming decades due to automation. Specifically, 77% think it's realistic that robots and computers might one day be able to do many of the jobs currently done by humans, with 20% describing this prospect as extremely realistic [10].

Regarding their feelings towards this concept, Americans generally express more worry than enthusiasm. Image4 illustrates that 6% are very enthusiastic, 27% are somewhat enthusiastic, 47% are not too enthusiastic, and 20% are not at all enthusiastic about the concept. On the other side, 25% are very worried, 48% are somewhat worried, 23% are not too worried, and 4% are not at all worried [9].

Furthermore, image5 shows that those who have heard a lot about the concept are more likely to find it extremely realistic, with 48% of those who have heard a lot finding it extremely realistic, compared to 14% who have heard a little and 4% who have heard nothing [6]. Additionally, those who have heard a lot about the concept are more likely to be enthusiastic about the notion, with 47% expressing some level of enthusiasm, compared to 30% who have heard a little and 18% who have heard nothing [5].

In conclusion, Americans perceive the concept of machines performing jobs currently done by humans as both plausible and concerning, with a majority finding it realistic but expressing more worry than enthusiasm [9].

The public has mixed opinions on limiting machine use in the workforce and replacing human jobs. According to [1], even though driverless vehicles could become widespread within the next half-century, more than half of the public would not want to ride in them today, with many expressing concerns about turning life-or-death decisions over to machines. However, [9] shows that 85% of Americans favor limiting robots and computers to doing jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans, with nearly half (47%) strongly favoring this policy.

![Limiting machines to dangerous jobs](image4)  
This image shows public opinion on limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, with 47% strongly favoring it and 38% favoring it.

Additionally, [7] indicates that nearly six-in-ten Americans (58%) feel there should be limits on how many jobs businesses can replace with machines, while 41% believe businesses are justified in replacing humans with machines if they can do the job better at a lower cost. [2] also highlights that both Republicans and Democrats are largely in agreement on the need for limits on the number of human jobs that can be replaced by machines, with 54% of Republicans and 60% of Democrats supporting this view.

![Opinions on replacing human jobs](image2)  
This image depicts opinions on whether businesses should be limited in the number of human jobs they can replace with machines, showing 58% in favor of limits.

Overall, the public is more supportive of policies that limit the use of machines to specific situations and bring human beings more fully into their operations, as mentioned in [5]. The majority of Americans support limiting machines to performing dangerous and dirty jobs, and there is broad support for policies such as a universal basic income or national service program for displaced workers, as noted in [6].

![Job Availability Perceptions](image1)  
[1] Perceptions of job availability have become more polarized along partisan lines, with Republicans generally more optimistic about job availability than Democrats. For instance, 71% of Republicans say there are plenty of jobs available, compared with 53% of Democrats. This gap has widened over time, reflecting a consistent trend in the data.

The image above (image1) illustrates this divide, showing that while 60% of the total population believes there are plenty of jobs available, this is largely driven by Republican and Republican-leaning voters. Among Republicans, 71% say there are plenty of jobs, whereas only 53% of Democrats hold this view. This disparity is even more pronounced when considering "good jobs" rather than just "jobs," where Republicans are more likely to believe good jobs are plentiful.

Despite these differences, there is a notable shift in public perception over time. [4] The public’s perceptions of the availability of jobs have undergone a similar transformation, with a clear majority of Americans now saying there are plenty of jobs in their communities. However, this positive sentiment is not uniformly shared across all political affiliations.

![Public Satisfaction Over Time](image2)  
[9] While there is optimism about job availability, favorable opinions about the economy and jobs have not been accompanied by a rise in public satisfaction with national conditions. The graph (image2) shows a long-term decline in public satisfaction with the way things are going in the country, with only 26% of Americans expressing satisfaction as of the latest survey, down from 33% in September. This decline is observed across both parties, indicating a broader dissatisfaction with national conditions despite positive views on local job markets.

In summary, perceptions of job availability differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with Republicans generally more optimistic about the job market than Democrats. [1]

The perception of racial discrimination varies significantly between Latino Democrats and Republicans, as highlighted by several survey findings. According to the data, a majority of Latino Democrats believe that people not seeing racial discrimination where it really does exist is a bigger problem. This disparity is further illustrated in image3, which shows that among Latinos, 61% do not see racial discrimination where it really does exist, while 35% see it where it doesn't. For Latino Democrats, the percentage of those who do not see racial discrimination where it exists is 73%, whereas for Republicans, it is 36% [3]. 

Additionally, image4 provides further insight into these differences, showing that Hispanic registered voters have a disapproval rate of 54%, while Democrats/Lean Democrats have a lower disapproval rate of 34%. In conclusion, Latino Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe that people not seeing racial discrimination where it really does exist is a bigger problem.

The trends of median investments in Europe and the U.S. from 2004 to 2009 show distinct patterns across different investment stages. In the U.S., the Seed stage investment remained relatively stable around €2M throughout the period, with a slight decline by 2009. The First stage investment started just above €2M in 2004, peaked around 2007, and then decreased to just above €2M by 2009. The Second stage investment started slightly above €4M in 2004, increased, peaked around 2006/2007, and then declined to below €4M by 2009. The Later stage investment started below €8M in 2004, peaked around 2007, and then saw a sharp decline, nearing €6M by 2009. ![Median U.S. Investments](image2) 

In contrast, the European investment trends show more moderate fluctuations. The Seed stage investment also showed a relatively stable trend around €2M, with a slight decline by 2009. The First stage investment in Europe started just above €2M in 2004, but showed less variation over the years. The Second stage investment in Europe started slightly above €4M in 2004, increased, and then declined to below €4M by 2009. The Later stage investment in Europe peaked around 2007-2008, similar to the U.S., but with a sharper decline by 2009. ![Median European Investments](image5)

Overall, both regions experienced a peak in investment activities around 2006-2007, followed by a decline across all categories by 2009. However, the U.S. showed more pronounced fluctuations, especially in the Later stage investments, while Europe maintained more consistent trends.

The document evaluates levels of confidence and likelihood through a combination of expert assessment, consensus among author teams, and analysis of available evidence. Confidence is determined based on the type, amount, quality, strength, and consistency of evidence, as well as the degree of expert agreement on the finding. Confidence ranges from low (inconclusive evidence or disagreement among experts) to very high (strong evidence and high consensus) [9]. 

![Confidence Levels](image2)

Likelihood, on the other hand, describes the probability of an impact occurring and is based on probabilistic measures of uncertainty, such as statistical analysis of observations or expert judgment. Likelihood ranges from very unlikely (less than or equal to a 1 in 10 chance of the outcome occurring) to very likely (greater than or equal to a 9 in 10 chance) [3]. 

![Probability Terms](image3)

Each Key Finding includes both confidence and likelihood designations, which are determined by assessing the available literature, evaluating the quality and quantity of evidence, and considering the level of agreement across different studies [5]. The Traceable Account section provides detailed documentation of the process used to reach these conclusions [2].

The perception of political parties' ethics and extremism varies significantly among different educational and political affiliation groups, as illustrated by the data provided. For instance, among those with at least a college degree, 31% say “high ethical standards” does not describe either the GOP or the Democratic Party, while 43% believe it describes one party but not the other, and 17% think it applies to both [3]. This indicates a more nuanced view among higher-educated individuals regarding the ethical standards of both parties.

![High ethical standards](image4)  
This image shows how different demographic groups perceive the political parties in terms of having "high ethical standards." It breaks down the percentages across various categories including education levels and political affiliation, highlighting that a significant portion of the public believes neither party has high ethical standards, particularly among independents and those with higher education levels.

Regarding extremism, the image also reveals that the Republican Party is perceived as more extreme than the Democratic Party, with 48% of Americans viewing the GOP as too extreme compared to 42% for the Democratic Party [9]. This perception is consistent across different educational backgrounds, though it may be more pronounced among certain political affiliations.

![Perceptions of political parties](image2)  
This image compares perceptions of the Republican and Democratic parties on three key traits: having good policy ideas, having high ethical standards, and being too extreme. It shows that both parties are rated equally on policy ideas (50%), with the Democratic Party slightly ahead in ethical standards (42% vs. 41%), and the Republican Party more likely to be seen as too extreme (48% vs. 42%).

These differences highlight the complex and often divided views on the ethical and ideological standing of political parties among various educational and political affiliation groups.

The perception of ethical standards and extremism between the Republican and Democratic parties varies significantly based on education levels and political affiliation. According to the data, a majority of Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) view their own party as having high ethical standards, while only 41% of Americans say the GOP has high ethical standards, and a nearly identical share (42%) says this about the Democratic Party [9]. This suggests that partisans are more positive about their own party's ethical standards than the opposing party.

Regarding extremism, more people view the Republican Party as "too extreme" (48%) than the Democratic Party (42%) [3]. This indicates a stronger perception of Republican extremism compared to Democratic extremism. However, views of the Republican Party as too extreme have declined since last June, while views of the Democratic Party remain relatively stable [3].

Education levels also play a role in these perceptions. Among those with at least a college degree, 31% say "high ethical standards" does not describe either party, while 43% say it describes one but not the other, and 17% think it describes both [8]. In contrast, fewer of those with some college experience (26%) or a high school degree or less (20%) think neither party has high ethical standards [5]. This suggests that higher education levels are associated with a more divided view of ethical standards between the two parties.

Political affiliation further influences these perceptions. Partisan views are deeply divided along partisan lines, with overwhelming shares of both Republicans and Democrats saying their own party has good policy ideas, while less than a quarter say this describes the opposing party [7]. This indicates that political affiliation strongly shapes perceptions of both ethical standards and extremism.

The 2016 U.S. presidential election saw distinct voter reactions compared to previous elections, with a notable emphasis on negative emotions and surprise. According to the data, **51% of voters felt hopeful** about Trump's victory, while **36% felt proud**, indicating a mix of positive emotions. However, **53% felt uneasy**, **41% sad**, and **41% scared**, reflecting a more negative emotional landscape than past elections. This is evident in the bar chart showing emotional reactions, where **hopeful** and **proud** are highlighted alongside **uneasy**, **sad**, and **scared** [image2].

In contrast, previous elections, such as the 2008 Obama election, had more positive reactions. For instance, **69% of voters felt hopeful** when asked how Obama made them feel, while only **35% felt uneasy** [image2]. The 2016 election was also marked by a higher level of surprise, with **73% of all voters** surprised that Trump won, including **87% of Clinton voters** [image4]. This surprise was particularly pronounced among Clinton supporters, who were **87% surprised**, compared to **60% of Trump voters** who were surprised [image4].

Furthermore, the 2016 election campaign was described as far more negative than past elections, with less discussion of issues and more focus on negativity [image7]. Voter turnout percentages also showed a decline, with **50%** for Trump in 2016, compared to **58%** for Obama in 2008 [image3].

Overall, the 2016 election was characterized by a more negative emotional response and a higher level of surprise compared to previous elections, with **hopefulness and pride** being the most prevalent emotions among Trump voters, while **unease, sadness, and fear** were more common among Clinton voters [image5].

The emotional reactions to Trump's election differ significantly between Trump and Clinton voters. Trump voters predominantly felt hopeful (96%) and proud (74%), as shown in the image [image5]. In contrast, Clinton voters felt uneasy (90%), sad (77%), and scared (76%), with a notable percentage also feeling angry (62%). This stark difference in emotional responses is highlighted in the text quotes [1] and [8], which emphasize the contrasting feelings of hope and pride among Trump supporters versus unease, sadness, and fear among Clinton supporters.

When comparing these emotional reactions to their expectations of Trump's first term, the data shows a similar trend. According to the text quote [4], voters are optimistic about Trump’s first term, with 56% believing it will be successful. However, this optimism is lower than the 67% who expected Obama to have a successful first term eight years prior. The image [image3] further illustrates this by showing that 58% of Clinton voters are willing to give Trump a chance, while 39% are not, indicating a divided perspective on his potential leadership.

In summary, Trump voters generally feel positive emotions about his election and have more optimistic expectations for his first term, while Clinton voters experience negative emotions and have more pessimistic expectations.

The perspectives about the potential success of Trump's first term and willingness to give him a chance differ significantly between Trump and Clinton voters. According to the data, **97%** of Trump voters expect him to have a successful first term, which is comparable to the **92%** of Obama voters who expected their candidate to be successful in 2008. This optimism is reflected in the image, which shows a bar chart comparing perceived success between Trump 2016 and Obama 2008, with Trump voters showing a higher percentage of expecting success [image4].

In contrast, only **15%** of Clinton supporters think Trump’s first term will be successful, while **76%** believe it will be unsuccessful [4]. This stark difference highlights the negative views Clinton voters have towards Trump's presidency.

Regarding willingness to give Trump a chance, **58%** of Clinton voters say they are "willing to give Trump a chance and see how he governs," but **39%** say they can't see themselves giving Trump a chance because of the kind of person he has shown himself to be [10]. This is illustrated in the image, which shows two groups with percentages indicating their willingness to support Trump [image3].

Trump voters, on the other hand, show high confidence in Trump's ability to be a good president, with **88%** confident about the kind of president he will be, while only **10%** have serious concerns [image1]. This confidence is a key difference between the two groups, reflecting their differing perceptions of Trump's character and leadership capabilities.

The priorities for Trump's presidency differ significantly between Trump and Clinton voters, reflecting their distinct views on his leadership. According to the data, **health care** is the top priority for Trump voters, with **29%** naming it as their main concern, compared to only **12%** of Clinton voters [1]. This indicates that Trump voters are more focused on healthcare reforms, possibly related to the Affordable Care Act [6].

In contrast, **Clinton voters** are more concerned with **unifying the country**, with **12%** of them suggesting this as a top priority, while **5%** of Trump voters hold the same view [8]. This suggests that Clinton voters may be more interested in addressing social divisions and personal behavior changes, which aligns with their perception of Trump's leadership style [8].

Regarding the economy, **Trump voters** are more likely to prioritize it, with **15%** citing it as a top issue, compared to **9%** of Clinton voters [6]. However, **Clinton voters** are more likely to focus on **environmental issues and climate change**, with **6%** of them considering these as important [3].

The image1 shows a detailed breakdown of these priorities, highlighting the differences between the groups. ![Health care, Economy, Immigration, Unify the country, Jobs/Unemployment, Change personal behavior/Address divisions he has created, Defense/National security, Environmental issues/Climate change, Foreign policy](image1)

Additionally, the image2 illustrates that **Trump voters** have a much clearer idea of where Trump wants to lead the country, with **87%** having a good idea, compared to only **14%** of Clinton voters [5]. This suggests that Trump voters are more confident in his leadership vision, while Clinton voters perceive his goals as less clear.

These differences in priorities and perceptions highlight the divergent views on Trump's leadership among the two groups. Trump voters seem to be more focused on healthcare, the economy, and immigration, while Clinton voters are more concerned with unifying the country and addressing environmental issues. The confidence of Trump voters in his leadership vision further underscores their differing perspectives on his direction as president.

The political orientations of Democratic and Republican voters have shown distinct shifts over time, as illustrated by various data points and visual representations. For instance, Republican and Republican-leaning voters have consistently favored a more conservative direction for their party, with 60% expressing a desire for conservatism in 2016, compared to 36% wanting more moderation [4]. This trend has been consistent over recent years, indicating a stable preference for conservatism among Republicans.

In contrast, Democratic voters have become more supportive of a more liberal direction than they were after previous elections. As of 2016, about half of all Democratic and Democratic-leaning voters (49%) said the party should move in a more liberal direction, while nearly as many (47%) favored a more moderate stance [7]. This shows a significant increase from earlier years, reflecting a growing inclination towards liberalism among Democrats.

Comparing these trends to the 2016 election outcomes, there is a notable divide between Trump and Clinton voters. Trump voters overwhelmingly expressed happiness that the GOP retained congressional control, with 94% feeling this way, while Clinton supporters were mostly unhappy, with 87% feeling this way [8]. This stark difference highlights the impact of the election results on voter sentiment.

In 2008, after Barack Obama's election, a majority of voters supported political leaders working with the new president. For instance, 74% of all voters believed Republican leaders should work with Obama, while 22% felt they should stand up to him. Among Republicans or those leaning Republican, 59% supported working with Obama, with 36% preferring to stand up to him. Among Democrats or those leaning Democratic, 86% wanted Republicans to work with Obama, while 11% preferred them to stand up to him [1].

In contrast, in 2016, the sentiment was different. The image shows that among all voters, 59% believed Democratic leaders should work with Trump to get things done, even if it means disappointing their supporters, while 39% felt they should stand up to Trump on important issues. Among Republicans or those leaning Republican, 84% preferred working with Trump, while 14% preferred standing up to him. Among Democrats or those leaning Democratic, 32% supported working with Trump, and 65% supported standing up to him [1].

This indicates a significant shift in voter expectations and sentiments towards political leaders working with or against newly elected presidents between 2008 and 2016. In 2008, there was a higher level of support for cooperation with the new president, whereas in 2016, there was a greater inclination towards standing up to the new president, especially among Democrats.

The 2016 election was marked by intense political polarization and a heightened sense of negativity, as evidenced by both voter perceptions of political entities and the level of negative campaigning. According to the data, voters perceived the campaign as extraordinarily negative, with **92%** saying there was more "mudslinging" or negative campaigning than in past elections, a significant increase from previous years [7]. This trend is further illustrated in **image1**, which shows a clear upward trend in the percentage of voters who believed there was more mudslinging in recent elections, reaching **92%** in 2016, the highest recorded since 1988.

![More mudslinging](image1)  
[1]

This negativity extended to how voters perceived various political entities. For instance, **image4** reveals that most voters gave low grades to the press, pollsters, and even the parties themselves. Only **22%** of voters gave the press an A or B, while **38%** gave it a failing grade. Similarly, **30%** of voters gave the Republican Party an F, and **28%** gave the Democratic Party an F, indicating widespread dissatisfaction with the performance of political institutions [4].

Voter emotions also reflected this negativity. **Image3** shows that **53%** of voters felt "uneasy" about Trump's victory, while **51%** felt "hopeful." However, **7%** of Clinton voters felt hopeful, and only **1%** felt proud, highlighting the stark contrast in emotional responses between the two groups [1]. 

The perception of negativity was not limited to the campaign itself but also influenced how voters viewed the candidates and the overall election process. **Image2** indicates that **84%** of Clinton voters believed that the election should have been a matter of concern, whereas **26%** of Trump voters believed it should not have been a matter of concern, reflecting deep ideological divides [2].

In summary, the 2016 election was characterized by a high level of negativity, with voters expressing strong negative opinions about the campaign, the candidates, and the political entities involved. This sentiment was reflected in both the level of mudslinging and the emotional responses of voters.

The emotional reactions of Trump and Clinton voters following the 2016 election are quite distinct. For Trump supporters, "happy" is the most common word used to describe their reaction, reflecting their surprise or shock at the election result [4]. In contrast, Clinton voters often use words like "shocked," "disappointed," and "disgusted" to express their feelings [8]. These differences highlight the varied emotional responses to Trump's victory.

![{The image shows the emotional reactions of Trump and Clinton voters.}] (image3)

The overall perception of Trump's performance is also negative. Voters grade other campaign actors just as harshly, with only about a quarter giving an A or B to the Republican Party (22%) and the Democratic Party (26%) [3]. The perception of mudslinging in the election is also high, with 92% of voters saying there was more "mudslinging" or negative campaigning than in past elections [7]. 

![{The graph shows the percentage of voters who say there was more mudslinging in various election years.}] (image1)

These findings indicate that while Trump voters felt hopeful and proud, Clinton voters felt uneasy, sad, and scared. The high level of mudslinging and the negative perception of Trump's performance contribute to these differing emotional reactions.

The emotional reactions to Trump's victory differ significantly between Trump and Clinton voters, reflecting their varying expectations prior to the election. For Trump voters, "happy" is the most common reaction, indicating satisfaction with the outcome, while many express surprise or shock at the election result [8]. In contrast, Clinton voters predominantly feel "shocked" and "disappointed," highlighting their disillusionment with the result [7]. These differences suggest that Trump voters were more optimistic about his presidency, whereas Clinton voters had higher expectations for a different outcome [10].

![{Clinton voters are predominantly shocked and disappointed, while Trump voters are happy and surprised}](image3)

The data also shows that a majority of all voters were surprised by Trump's victory, with 87% of Clinton voters and 60% of Trump voters expressing surprise [5]. This indicates that both groups had unexpected results, but Clinton voters were more likely to be surprised, which may reflect their higher expectations for a different outcome [3].

![{Most voters were surprised by Trump's victory, with Clinton voters being the most surprised}](image2)

These emotional responses reveal that Trump voters were more satisfied with the outcome, while Clinton voters were more dissatisfied, suggesting that their expectations prior to the election were different [10].

The question explores how voter sentiments towards Trump's victory and expectations for a female president in their lifetime differ between Trump and Clinton voters. According to text quote [1], a sizable majority (79%) of voters still expect there will be a female president "in their lifetime," with no significant differences in these opinions among men and women, or Clinton supporters and Trump backers. This suggests that both groups have similar expectations regarding a female president.

Regarding sentiments towards Trump's victory, text quote [5] indicates that overall, 73% of all voters say they are surprised that Trump won the election, including 87% of Clinton voters. A somewhat smaller 60% -majority of Trump voters express surprise at the outcome, though 40% say they are not surprised he won. This is further supported by image1, which shows that 60% of Trump voters were surprised, while 87% of Clinton voters were surprised. 

Text quote [7] also highlights that 97% of Trump voters say they are happy he won, while 93% of Clinton voters say they are unhappy. This indicates a significant difference in sentiments towards Trump's victory between the two groups.

In terms of expectations for a female president, both groups have similar expectations, as indicated by text quote [1]. However, the sentiments towards Trump's victory show a clear divergence between the two groups, with Trump voters being more positive and Clinton voters more negative.

![Percentage of voters who answered "Yes" to a specific question](image2)

In conclusion, while both Trump and Clinton voters have similar expectations regarding a female president in their lifetime, there is a significant difference in their sentiments towards Trump's victory, with Trump voters being more positive and Clinton voters more negative.

This trend is consistent across different age groups, with older Americans being particularly critical, as noted in [7].

In summary, Republicans are more critical of China's handling of the pandemic compared to Democrats, and these perceptions have generally become more negative over time.

The survey data reveals that a significant portion of Americans hold China responsible for the coronavirus outbreak. This is further supported by [7], which states that half of Americans think the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the pandemic, even if it means worsening economic relations.

![Americans are highly critical of the way China has handled the coronavirus outbreak. Around two-thirds (64%) say China has done a bad job, including 43% who say it has done a very bad job.](image3)

![The image contains survey data visualized in a bar and pie chart about U.S. public opinion on U.S.-China relations and the role of China in the coronavirus outbreak. The charts show the following:](image1)

Political affiliations in the U.S. and Germany significantly influence preferences for foreign policy partners and desired cooperation levels, as evidenced by several key points from the provided data.

In the U.S., political affiliation dictates who people think is the most important foreign policy partner. While both Republicans and Democrats agree that the UK is their most important partner, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are keener on Israel as a partner (26%) than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (9%). Democrats also place more emphasis on Canada and Mexico for their top foreign policy affiliate. However, views of Germany are similar among partisans in the U.S., with both sides ranking Germany fifth on the list of most or second-most important foreign policy partners. ![Germany as a Foreign Policy Partner](image2)

For Germans, the differences are less dramatic. Supporters of the CDU/CSU, as well as those who support the SPD and Greens, name France as the first or second-most important partner, followed by the U.S. ![German Political Affiliations and Foreign Policy Partners](image5)

When it comes to cooperation with other countries, there is again a divergence between American and German views. Nearly seven-in-ten Americans (69%) say that they want to cooperate more with Germany, compared with only half of Germans who say the same about the U.S. Nonetheless, the percentage of Germans who say they want to cooperate more with the U.S. has increased nine points since 2018. At that time, fully 47% wanted to cooperate less with America. ![Cooperation with Other Countries](image2)

Democrats in the U.S. are more likely to want greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans. And in Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU are more willing to want greater cooperation with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD. This jibes with data on the international image of the U.S., where those on the ideological right in Germany tend to be more favorable toward the U.S. overall. ![Political Affiliations and Cooperation](image3)

There are also slight partisan differences in the U.S. on the choice of a close relationship with Russia or Germany. About two-thirds of Democrats (66%) say they prefer close ties with Germany, compared with 57% of Republicans. And 31% of Republicans prefer close relations with Russia compared with 21% among Democrats. ![Partisan Differences in Foreign Policy Preferences](image4)

In terms of cooperation with Russia, Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration. Increased cooperation with Russia is a more common preference among Republicans in the U.S. (41%) than Democrats (32%), as well as among Germans living in former East Germany (75%) than in the former West (63%). ![Cooperation with Russia](image7)

These findings highlight how political affiliations shape foreign policy preferences and cooperation levels in both the U.S. and Germany.

In contrast, Germans are more likely to prefer the U.S. over Russia, with 39% favoring the U.S. and 25% favoring Russia. Americans have several key concerns regarding China, with economic issues, human rights, and military power being among the most prominent. According to text quote [2], when Americans think of China, human rights and the economy are top of mind. Text quote [9] highlights that Americans express substantial concern about eight specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship, with cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power, and China’s policies on human rights standing out as particularly serious problems.

![China Concerns Over Time](image1)  
This image shows the change in percentage from 2020 to 2021 on various issues related to China. For instance, the percentage of Americans who believe cyberattacks from China are a serious problem increased from 58% in 2020 to 65% in 2021. Similarly, the percentage of Americans who think China's policies on human rights are a very serious problem for the U.S. increased from 43% in 2020 to 50% in 2021. These trends indicate a growing concern over these issues.

Text quote [10] further supports this by noting that half of Americans now say China’s policy on human rights is a very serious problem for the U.S., up 7 percentage points since last year. Additionally, nine-in-ten Americans say China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people.

The level of confidence in dealing with China also varies. Text quote [5] indicates that while 60% of Americans have confidence in Biden to do the right thing regarding world affairs in general, only 53% say they have confidence in him to handle China effectively. This suggests a lower level of confidence in Biden's ability to manage the U.S.-China relationship compared to other foreign policy issues.

![Confidence in Handling Global Issues](image2)  
This image shows the level of confidence people have in dealing with various global issues, including dealing effectively with China. It reveals that 46% have no confidence in dealing effectively with China, which is lower than the confidence levels in other issues like improving relationships with allies or dealing with terrorism.

Political views also play a role in how Americans perceive China. Text quote [6] states that Republicans are significantly more likely to say the U.S. should get tougher on China on economic issues and to describe China as an enemy rather than a competitor or partner. This is reflected in image [5], which shows a significant increase in the percentage of Republicans/leaning Republicans who feel "cold" toward China from 57% in 2018 to 79% in 2021.

In summary, Americans have key concerns regarding China, including economic issues, human rights, and military power, with these concerns showing an increasing trend over time. The level of confidence in handling these issues varies, with Republicans expressing more concern and less confidence in dealing with China compared to Democrats.

Since 2008, most Latino subgroups have shown increased optimism about their finances. For instance, the percentage of Latinos expecting their family’s finances to improve "a lot" or "some" rose from 67% in 2008 to 81% in 2015, a 14 percentage point increase [10]. This trend is evident across various demographic groups, with the largest gains observed among those with higher education levels. Specifically, Latinos who had completed some college saw economic optimism grow roughly twice as fast since 2008 compared to those with a high school diploma or less [2].

![General population and All Hispanics financial expectations change](image3)  
This image shows the change in financial expectations for the general population and all Hispanics from 2008 to 2015. The general population's optimism increased by 6 percentage points, while all Hispanics' optimism increased by 14 percentage points, indicating a significant gap [3].

The data also reveals that optimism has increased among different subgroups. For example, Latino men showed a +18 percentage point increase, while Latina women showed a +11 percentage point increase in their financial optimism [6]. Additionally, younger and middle-aged Hispanics were more optimistic than older Latinos [7].

![Demographic groups and financial optimism changes](image1)  
This image compares the financial optimism changes across different demographic groups, showing that the percentage of Hispanics expecting their family’s finances to improve has increased significantly for all groups, with the highest increases among those with higher education levels [2].

In contrast, the general population's financial optimism has not kept pace with that of Latinos. While the general population's optimism increased by 6 percentage points from 2008 to 2015, Latinos' optimism increased by 14 percentage points, highlighting a growing gap [3].

![Perceived economic well-being of different Hispanic groups](image2)  
This image illustrates the perceived economic well-being of different Hispanic groups, showing that a significant proportion of surveyed Hispanics believe they are economically better off than before, with variations across different demographics [2].

Overall, the financial optimism among different Hispanic subgroups has increased significantly from 2008 to 2015, outpacing the general population's increase in optimism [3].

The financial expectations of Hispanics for their children are significantly influenced by both their current financial situations and educational levels. According to the data, Hispanics with a positive view of their current financial situation are more likely to expect their family’s finances will improve over the next 12 months [3]. This optimism is also reflected in their expectations about their children's financial futures, with about seven-in-ten Hispanic adults expecting their children will be better off financially than they themselves are [6].

![Hispanic financial optimism over time](image1)  
This line graph shows that from 2004 to 2015, Hispanic optimism about their financial situation has fluctuated, but generally remained higher than the general public's optimism. The shaded area between 2007 and 2009 might indicate a period of economic uncertainty that affected Hispanic financial outlooks.

Educational attainment also plays a role in these expectations. Among those with at least some college experience, 69% expect their children will be better off financially, while high school graduates are more optimistic, with 79% predicting the same [5]. This suggests that higher education may contribute to a more positive financial outlook for future generations.

![Financial condition expectations](image2)  
This segmented bar chart illustrates that individuals with excellent financial conditions are more likely to expect improvement, while those with poor conditions are less optimistic. However, the overall trend shows that most Hispanics, regardless of their current financial status, are optimistic about their children's financial futures.

Age also affects these expectations, with younger Latinos being more optimistic than older ones. For example, 75% of Latinos ages 18 to 29 expect their children will be better off, compared to 52% of those ages 65 and older [9]. This indicates that younger generations may have more confidence in their children's financial prospects.

![Perceived economic well-being of different Hispanic groups](image5)  
This bar chart shows that across various demographic subgroups, a majority of Hispanics believe they are better off economically compared to previous times. However, there are variations, with some groups showing higher levels of optimism than others.

In summary, current financial situations and educational levels are key factors that influence the financial expectations of Hispanics for their children. Those with more favorable financial conditions and higher educational attainment tend to be more optimistic about their children's financial futures.

The perceptions of financial well-being among Latinos have shown a positive trend from 2000 to 2015, with increasing optimism about their family's financial future. In 2004, only 31% of Latinos believed their family's finances would improve, but by 2015, this percentage had risen to 81% [4]. This increase is more significant compared to the general public, which saw its percentage rise from 51% in 2004 to 61% in 2015 [image4]. The data indicates that Hispanic opinions or attitudes have remained generally higher and increased to a greater extent than the general public's over this time period on financial well-being [image4].

![Hispanic and General Public Financial Well-Being](image4)  
![Percentage of Hispanics Expecting Better Financial Future](image4)

In terms of unemployment trends, the Latino unemployment rate has been declining from 2000 to 2015, though it remains above its 2006 low. In 2000, the unemployment rate for Latinos was 5.8%, and by 2015, it had decreased to 6.4%. However, this rate is still higher than that of non-Hispanic workers, which dropped from 3.8% in 2000 to 4.8% in 2015 [image5]. Despite the overall decline, the unemployment rate for Latinos has not fully recovered to pre-recession levels, as noted in the data [6].

![Unemployment Rates for Hispanics and Non-Hispanics](image5)  
![Quarterly Unemployment Rates](image5)

Overall, while there has been an improvement in the economic situation for Latinos, particularly in terms of financial well-being and employment rates, they still face challenges compared to the general population.

The trends in unemployment rates and economic perceptions between Hispanic and non-Hispanic populations reveal significant differences. According to the data, the U.S. Latino unemployment rate has declined since the Great Recession but remains above its 2006 low, as shown in ![Hispanic unemployment rate compared to non-Hispanic](image5). In 2015, the Hispanic unemployment rate was 6.4%, compared to 4.8% for non-Hispanics, indicating that Hispanics still face higher unemployment rates despite improvements.

Economic perceptions also differ. The image shows that Hispanic individuals are more optimistic about their financial situation, with 76% feeling better off in 2004, 67% in 2008, 73% in 2011, and 81% in 2015, compared to the general public's 70%, 56%, 58%, and 61% respectively, as depicted in ![Comparison of attitudes or opinions of Hispanic individuals and the general public](image4). This suggests that even though Hispanics face higher unemployment rates, they tend to have more positive views about their economic status.

These trends contribute to income and wealth disparities. The image illustrates that median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, reaching $42,491 in 2014, while the general public's income was higher at $53,700, as shown in ![Comparison of income and poverty rates for Hispanic and all U.S. households](image2). Additionally, the poverty rate for Hispanics was 23.6% in 2014, significantly higher than the 14.8% for all U.S. households. Wealth disparities are also evident, with Hispanic households having a much lower median wealth compared to all U.S. households, as shown in the same image.

In summary, while Hispanic unemployment rates have improved, they remain higher than those of non-Hispanics, and Hispanics generally have more positive economic perceptions, which may partially offset some of the income and wealth disparities. However, these disparities persist, as indicated by the data.

![Unemployment Rates for Hispanic and Non-Hispanic Groups](image5)

Text quote [3] indicates that in 2015, about half (53%) of Latinos said their family income is not keeping up with the cost of living, while 10% said it is going up faster than the cost of living. The variation in internet usage and device ownership among seniors compared to all adults is evident from several sources. According to the data, while younger adults have high rates of internet use, seniors show a notable decline. For instance, [5] mentions that internet use and broadband adoption among seniors each fall off notably starting at approximately age 75. This trend is further supported by [10], which highlights that device ownership among older adults differs notably from the population as a whole.

![Internet Usage by Age Group](image1)  
This image shows that the percentage of internet users who go online daily or almost every day decreases with age. For example, 88% of 18-29 year olds go online daily, whereas only 71% of 65+ year olds do so. Similarly, the percentage of those who go online 3-5 times per week also decreases, with 6% of 18-29 year olds compared to 11% of 65+ year olds.

![Internet and Broadband Usage by Age Group](image2)  
This image illustrates that both internet usage and broadband availability decrease with age. For example, at age 75-79, only 47% of people go online, and 34% have broadband at home. In contrast, at age 65-69, 74% go online and 65% have broadband at home.

Device ownership among seniors is also lower than in the general adult population. [10] indicates that for smartphones, 55% of all adults own one, while only 18% of those aged 65 and over do. Similarly, for tablets or e-readers, 43% of all adults own one, compared to 27% of seniors.

![Smartphone and Tablet Ownership by Age Group](image3)  
This image shows the difference in smartphone and tablet ownership between all adults and those aged 65 and over. It clearly demonstrates that seniors are less likely to own these devices compared to the general population.

![Online Usage Categories](image4)  
This pie chart categorizes online usage into three groups: those who do not go online, those who go online but do not use social networking services, and those who use social networking services. It shows that 41% of seniors do not go online, while 27% use social networking sites, indicating a significant portion of seniors either do not use the internet or use it for social purposes.

![Technology Adoption Between All Adults and Seniors](image5)  
This bar chart compares technology adoption between all adults and those aged 65+. It shows that seniors are less likely to own a cell phone, use the internet, or have broadband at home compared to all adults. For example, 91% of all adults own a cell phone, while only 77% of seniors do.

In summary, seniors are less likely to use the internet and own digital devices compared to all adults, with usage and ownership declining significantly with age. However, once seniors become internet users, they tend to make the internet a part of their daily routine, with 71% going online every day or almost every day.

The device ownership among older adults is generally lower compared to their internet usage patterns. While many older adults do use the internet regularly, as shown in [10], they tend to own less advanced devices like smartphones. For instance, only 18% of older adults own a smartphone, which is significantly lower than the majority of all Americans who have one [5]. However, older adults show a higher rate of ownership for tablets and e-book readers, with 27% owning either a tablet or an e-book reader, which is actually higher than the percentage of smartphone owners among this age group [7].

![Ownership Comparison](image4)  
This image highlights the difference in device ownership between all adults and those aged 65 and over. It shows that while 55% of all adults own a smartphone, only 18% of older adults do. Similarly, 43% of all adults own a tablet or e-reader, whereas 27% of older adults do.

Despite these lower rates of smartphone ownership, older adults still maintain a significant level of internet usage. According to [3], 59% of seniors report using the internet, which is a six percentage point increase from 2012. Moreover, 71% of older adults who use the internet go online every day or almost every day [10]. This suggests that while older adults may not own as many advanced devices as younger adults, they are still active users of the internet.

![Internet Usage Trends](image1)  
This graph illustrates the increasing trends in internet usage among both all adults and older adults from 2000 to 2013. The darker line represents all adults, showing an increase from around 50 in 2000 to 86 in 2013. The lighter line represents older adults, showing an increase from about 14 in 2000 to 59 in 2013. These trends indicate that while older adults have lower adoption rates compared to the general population, their usage is steadily increasing.

The differences in device ownership and online activity between seniors and the general adult population are evident from various data points. For instance, while 55% of all adults own a smartphone, only 18% of seniors do, as indicated by the bar chart in image3 [3]. Similarly, 43% of all adults own a tablet or e-reader, whereas 27% of seniors own one, highlighting a significant disparity in device ownership among older adults.

In terms of online activity, the table in image1 [1] shows that 59% of seniors go online, which is lower than the national adoption rate of 55% mentioned in text quote [4]. However, it also reveals that seniors aged 75-79 have a lower percentage of broadband connections at home compared to other age groups. The pie chart in image2 [2] further illustrates that a substantial portion of seniors do not use social networking sites, with 32% going online but not using SNS, and 41% not going online at all.

Trends in internet adoption over time for these groups are shown in image4 [4]. The line graph depicts an upward trend for both the general adult population and seniors, with seniors increasing from about 14 in 2000 to 59 in 2013. This indicates a growing adoption rate among seniors, although it still lags behind the general population's rate of 86% in 2013.

![Internet Adoption by Age Group](image1)  
![Online Usage Categories](image2)  
![Device Ownership Comparison](image3)  
![Adoption Trends Over Time](image4)  

Seniors have lower rates of smartphone and tablet ownership compared to the general adult population, but their internet adoption rates have been increasing over time, though they still lag behind the general population.

The device ownership trends among seniors show that while they are less likely to own smartphones compared to the general population, they have higher rates of owning tablets or e-book readers. According to the bar chart in image1, 18% of seniors own a smartphone, whereas 27% own a tablet or e-book reader. This is significant because it indicates that seniors are more inclined towards alternative devices that may be more user-friendly for their needs.

In terms of online social networking usage, the pie chart in image2 reveals that 27% of seniors use social networking sites such as Facebook, which is a notable figure considering the overall percentage of seniors who go online. It's also worth noting that despite lower overall usage rates, certain segments of the senior population have internet and broadband adoption rates that are equal to or even greater than those of the general public, as mentioned in text quote [6]. The table in image3 further illustrates that seniors are more likely to own a tablet or e-book reader than a smartphone, reinforcing the point made in image1. Additionally, the data from image5 shows that seniors who go online are more likely to have broadband at home, especially those with higher education levels and higher household incomes.

Overall, while seniors may not be as prevalent in smartphone ownership as the general public, their usage of social networking sites and ownership of tablets or e-book readers indicates a trend towards adopting technology that suits their lifestyle and needs.

The internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults vary significantly based on age, education, and income. For instance, younger, higher-income, and more highly educated seniors tend to use the internet and broadband at rates approaching or even exceeding those of the general population [8]. In contrast, seniors aged 80 and older, those with low household incomes, and those who have not attended college are much more removed from online life [10].

Overall, the data shows that internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults are influenced by age, education, and income, with younger, higher-income, and more educated seniors being more likely to adopt these technologies. The adoption rates of internet, broadband, cell phones, and smartphones among seniors vary significantly by income and education levels. For instance, [3] indicates that younger, higher-income, and more highly educated seniors use the internet and broadband at rates approaching the general population. Education also plays a crucial role. [9] states that college graduates have high adoption rates, with 87% going online and 76% being broadband adopters. On the other hand, those who have not attended college have much lower rates, with only 40% going online and 27% having broadband at home.

In summary, higher income and education levels are associated with higher adoption rates of internet, broadband, cell phones, and smartphones among seniors.

The adoption rates of the internet and smartphones among older adults (65+) vary significantly by income and education. ![Cell Phone and Smartphone Ownership Among Seniors](image4)

Overall, the adoption rates of the internet and smartphones among older adults (65+) are influenced by factors such as income and education, with higher rates observed among more affluent and educated seniors. These rates are generally lower compared to the overall trends in device ownership among the general population.

The variation in internet usage and smartphone ownership among seniors is influenced by their educational backgrounds. The impact of educational attainment on perceptions of workforce technologies is significant. According to the data, college graduates are more likely to view these technologies positively. For instance, 64% of college graduates feel that their education made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of high school graduates or less [10]. Similarly, 53% of college graduates believe technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement, versus 32% for high school graduates [10]. This suggests that higher education is associated with a more positive outlook on technological advancements in the workplace.

Regarding driverless car technology, there is a widespread expectation of its development and adoption in the coming decades. A majority of Americans (94%) have some awareness of the effort to develop driverless vehicles, and roughly two-thirds of the public anticipates that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next half-century. Specifically, 9% predict this will occur in the next 10 years [2].

![Expectations for driverless car technology](image2)

Workers with higher levels of education tend to have more positive views of workplace technologies compared to those with less education. Similarly, for smartphones, college graduates report 76% positive views compared to 54% for those with less education [4]. These differences are most pronounced in the case of office productivity tools, where there is a 45-percentage point difference in the share of workers with college degrees (90%) and those with high school diplomas or less (45%) who feel these technologies have had a positive impact professionally [4].

Regarding the expectations for the adoption of driverless cars, many Americans anticipate that automation technologies will make significant inroads in terms of their development and adoption in the coming decades. Fully 94% of Americans have some awareness of the effort to develop driverless vehicles, and roughly two-thirds of the public anticipates that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next half-century – with 9% predicting that this will occur in the next 10 years [1].

The perceptions of automation and workforce technology impacts differ significantly between future expectations for driverless vehicles and the current experiences of U.S. workers. Americans' levels of awareness about automation significantly influence their enthusiasm and worry regarding machines taking over human jobs. Those with high levels of awareness are more enthusiastic about the idea of robots and computers doing many human jobs, but they also express substantial concerns. For instance, 47% of high-awareness Americans express some level of enthusiasm about the notion that machines might one day do many of the jobs currently done by humans [7]. However, a similar share (47%) of these high-awareness Americans also express some level of worry about a future in which machines do many jobs currently done by humans [7].

![Concept Awareness and Emotions](image3)

The image shows that as awareness increases, so does the level of concern. For example, 76% of those who have heard a lot about the concept express some level of worry, compared to 69% of those who have not heard anything about it before [9]. This indicates that even among those who are more informed, there is still significant worry about the implications of automation.

In terms of expected outcomes, most Americans expect more negative than positive results from widespread automation. Around three-quarters of Americans expect increased inequality between rich and poor if machines can do many human jobs; just one-quarter think the economy would create many new, better-paying jobs for humans [8]. Additionally, when asked about various possible outcomes, the public generally expects more negative outcomes, such as increased inequality and difficulty finding things to do with their lives [4].

![Outcomes Expectations](image4)

The image illustrates that while some positive outcomes like economic efficiency are seen as possible, they are less likely than negative outcomes like increased inequality. The majority of respondents believe that the economy will not create many new, well-paying jobs for humans, with 75% thinking this is not likely to happen [1].

Overall, the data suggests that while there is some enthusiasm among those who are well-informed about automation, there is also considerable concern about the potential negative impacts on society and the economy.

Public opinion on workforce automation policies shows clear differences between Democrats and Republicans. Democrats are significantly more supportive of policies like a universal basic income and a national service program for displaced workers, with 77% of Democrats favoring a basic income compared to 38% of Republicans [5]. Similarly, 66% of Democrats support a national service program versus 46% of Republicans [9]. However, there is broad agreement across both parties on the idea of limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, with 85% of Americans supporting this policy [6].

![Limiting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs](image1)  
This image shows the public's support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs, with a majority favoring this policy.

![Public opinion on automation outcomes](image2)  
This image illustrates public sentiment on possible negative and positive outcomes of automation, highlighting strong support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs.

![Policy support by political affiliation](image3)  
This image provides a detailed breakdown of support for various policies among Democrats and Republicans, showing significant differences in favor of a universal basic income and a national service program, while both parties show high support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs.

![Public opinion on automation and job displacement](image4)  
This image details public opinion on the government's role in caring for displaced workers and the limits on job replacement by machines, showing alignment between Democrats and Republicans on the latter issue.

![Support for different automation policies](image5)  
This image shows the level of support for various policies related to automation, with a strong majority supporting the limitation of machines to dangerous jobs.

In summary, Democrats are more supportive of policies that provide financial security and social programs for displaced workers, while both parties show strong support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs.

Political affiliations and education levels significantly influence opinions on government obligations and automation limits related to job displacement. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more supportive of a universal basic income and national service programs for displaced workers, with 77% of Democrats favoring a basic income compared to 38% of Republicans (text [1], image2). Conversely, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to believe individuals should be responsible for their financial well-being even if jobs are automated (text [3], image4).

Educational differences also play a role, with those having lower levels of education more supportive of limiting the number of jobs that businesses can replace with machines. Specifically, 70% of those with high school diplomas or less support such limits, while only 41% of those with four-year college degrees do (text [10], image4). However, there is no significant educational difference in the belief that the government has an obligation to take care of displaced workers (text [10], image4).

Regarding automation limits, partisan opinions are much more aligned, with just over half of Republicans (54%) and 60% of Democrats supporting limits on how many human jobs businesses can replace with machines (text [7], image4). This aligns with the strong public support for limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, with 85% of Americans favoring this policy (image1, text [8]).

In summary, political affiliations and education levels shape opinions on government obligations and automation limits, with Democrats generally more supportive of government intervention and those with lower education levels more supportive of limiting automation.

Political affiliations significantly influence American views on policies related to workforce automation and job displacement. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more supportive of a universal basic income and a national service program in the event of widespread job losses due to automation, with 77% of Democrats favoring a universal basic income compared to 38% of Republicans [1]. Similarly, 66% of Democrats support a national service program versus 46% of Republicans [1].

There are no major partisan differences in support for limiting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs or for giving people the option to pay extra to interact with a human rather than a robot in commercial transactions [1]. However, attitudes towards the government’s obligation to take care of workers displaced by automation vary strongly by partisan affiliation. A majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe the government should have an obligation to take care of displaced workers, even if it means higher taxes for others, while a nearly identical share of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents feel individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [4].

Partisan opinions are much more aligned on the question of whether or not businesses should be limited in the number of human jobs they can replace with machines. Just over half of Republicans (54%) feel there should be limits to how many human jobs businesses can replace with machines, only slightly less than the 60% of Democrats who hold this view [6].

![Government Obligation and Limits on Automation](image3)  
This image illustrates public opinion on whether the government has an obligation to take care of displaced workers, versus whether individuals have an obligation to care for their own well-being if machines have taken many jobs, and whether there should be limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines.

Despite these pronounced differences toward this aspect of the workforce automation debate, partisan opinions are much more aligned on the question of whether or not businesses should be limited in the number of human jobs they can replace with machines [9].

Social media users across different age groups experience a variety of emotions from the content they encounter. According to the data, amusement is the most frequently experienced emotion, with 88% of users reporting that they see content on these sites that makes them feel amused. This is also the emotion that the largest share of users (44%) frequently experience on these sites [7]. 

![Amused](image2)  
The image shows that younger users (18-29) are more likely to feel amused than older users. For instance, 54% of younger adults say they frequently see content that makes them feel amused, compared to 30% of those 65 and older [5]. 

However, other emotions exhibit more variation based on age. Younger adults are more likely than older adults to say they frequently encounter content on social media that makes them feel lonely. Some 15% of social media users ages 18 to 29 say this, compared with 7% of those ages 30 to 49 and just 4% of those 50 and older [5]. Conversely, a relatively small share of older adults are frequently amused by content they see on social media. In fact, similar shares of social media users ages 65 and older say they frequently see content on these platforms that makes them feel amused (30%) and angry (24%) [5].

Other emotions such as anger, connectedness, inspiration, depression, and loneliness also vary by age group. For example, the percentage of users who feel angry ranges from 23% (65+) to 27% (18-29) [5]. 

In terms of the most frequently experienced emotions across all users, amusement remains the top emotion, followed by anger, connectedness, inspiration, depression, and loneliness [7]. 

![Emotions](image3)  
The image shows the frequency of different emotions experienced. Amusement is the most frequently experienced emotion, with 88% of users reporting that they see content on these sites that makes them feel amused. Anger is the second most frequently experienced emotion, with 71% of users reporting that they see content on these sites that makes them feel angry. 

In conclusion, different age groups react emotionally to social media content in various ways, with younger users more likely to feel amused and lonely, while older users are more likely to feel amused and angry. The most frequently experienced emotion across all users is amusement.

The emotional responses of different age groups to social media content vary significantly. Conversely, younger adults are also more likely to feel lonely, with 15% reporting this frequently, compared to just 4% of those 50 and older. Older adults, on the other hand, are less likely to feel amused but have more comparable frequencies of feeling angry, with 24% of those 65 and older frequently feeling angry, as noted in [7].
