The organizational structure of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is part of the Department of Space (DOS), which oversees various entities and programs. ISRO is under the DOS, with other key entities such as the Physical Research Laboratory (PRL), National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL), North Eastern-Space Applications Centre (NE-SAC), and Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) working in tandem to advance space science and technology. The DOS also manages Antrix Corporation Limited, which markets space products and services [7]. The organizational chart of the Department of Space illustrates this structure, showing the Prime Minister at the top, followed by the Space Commission, then the Department of Space, with ISRO and other entities like PRL, NARL, NE-SAC, SCL, IIST, ANTRIX, and specialized centers like VSSC, LPSC, SDSC-SHAR, ISAC, SAC, and NRSC underneath [3]. Further subdivisions include IPRC, IISU, DECU, MCF, ISTRAC, LEOS, and IIRS [3].

![Organizational structure of the Department of Space](image3)

The budget allocation for different programs related to space for the financial years 2015-2016 and 2016-2017 is represented in a bar chart. The categories listed are Space Technology, Space Applications, INSAT Operational, Space Sciences, and Direction & Administration and Other Programmes. Each category has three bars: blue for BE 2015-2016, red for RE 2015-2016, and green for BE 2016-2017. For example, Space Technology had a budget of 4596.2 for BE 2015-2016, 4351.78 for RE 2015-2016, and 5235.68 for BE 2016-2017. The grand total for the entire budget was 7388.19 for BE 2015-2016, 6959.44 for RE 2015-2016, and 7509.14 for BE 2016-2017 [1].

![Budgetary allocations in different programs related to space](image1)

The Indian Space Programme is supported by a network of centers and organizations, each playing a unique role in advancing space science and technology. Antrix Corporation Limited, for instance, serves as the commercial and marketing arm of ISRO, providing space products and services to international customers [4]. This includes end-to-end solutions ranging from hardware and software to complex spacecraft, covering communications, earth observation, and scientific missions [4].

The Department of Space (DOS) oversees the implementation of the Indian space programme, formulating policies and ensuring that space science and technology contribute to the socio-economic benefit of the country [3]. Under DOS, various centers operate, including the Space Commission, which formulates policies and oversees the implementation of the space programme [3]. The Physical Research Laboratory (PRL), National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL), North Eastern-Space Applications Centre (NE-SAC), and Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) are key entities that support the space programme through research and development [3].

NARL, located at Gadanki near Tirupati, focuses on atmospheric research with a vision to develop the capability to predict the behavior of the earth’s atmosphere through observations and modeling [9]. It operates under seven major groups, including Radar Application and Development Group and Iono-spheric and Space Research Group, and also engages in specific projects like the LIDAR project [8]. The MST Radar facility at NARL is used for atmospheric and meteorological research [3].

NE-SAC, located in Shillong, is a joint initiative between DOS and the North Eastern Council (NEC) aimed at providing developmental support to the North Eastern Region using space science and technology [6]. It has completed several applications projects and research and development projects under various missions, including Earth Observation Applications Mission and Disaster Management Support [6].

The Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) at Chandigarh focuses on creating a strong microelectronics base in the country, with activities centered on the Design, Development, Fabrication, Assembly, Testing, and Reliability Assurance of CMOS and MEMS Devices [10].

The budgetary allocations for these programs, as shown in the bar chart, reflect their importance. For example, Space Technology received significant funding in both 2015-2016 and 2016-2017, indicating its critical role in the space programme [1]. Similarly, Space Applications and INSAT Operational also received substantial funding, highlighting their significance in operational and application-based space activities [1].

![Budget Allocation](image1)
![Organizational Chart](image2)
![NARL MST Radar Facility](image3)
![Map of ISRO Locations](image4)

The budget allocation reflects the importance of these centers, with higher allocations indicating greater emphasis on certain areas of the space programme.

The National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) is a key institution in atmospheric research, with a vision to "Developing capability to predict the behaviour of the earth’s atmosphere through observations and modeling". NARL carries out its research activities under seven major groups, including Radar Application and Development Group, Ionospheric and Space Research Group, Atmospheric Structure and Dynamics Group, Cloud and Convective Systems Group, Aerosols, Radiation and Trace Gases Group, Weather and Climate Research Group, and Computers and Data Management Group. Apart from these groups, there are also specific projects such as the LIDAR project and Advanced Space-borne Instrument Development project. ![NARL's research groups and projects](image5) 

NARL gives equal emphasis to technology development, observations, data archival, dissemination, assimilation, and modeling. The MST Radar facility at NARL is used for atmospheric and meteorological research, featuring a large array of antennas or poles organized in a grid pattern for extensive coverage. This facility supports the laboratory's mission by providing critical data for weather prediction and atmospheric studies. 

On the other hand, the Semiconductor Laboratory (SCL) at Chandigarh focuses on the Design, Development, Fabrication, Assembly, Testing, and Reliability Assurance of CMOS and MEMS Devices. Up gradation of Wafer Fabrication Lab has been completed and $8"$ CMOS Wafer Fabrication Line is geared-up for production activities. Three production lots have been processed with ASICs/IPs/Test Chips designed in-house. In these lots, 28 designs have been fabricated and tested successfully. These chips include some complex ASICs, one of them being Vikram Processor for Launch Vehicles. ![SCL's semiconductor fabrication facilities](image4)

The facilities at both NARL and SCL are crucial for their respective functions. NARL's radar and atmospheric research facilities support the prediction of atmospheric behavior, while SCL's advanced semiconductor fabrication lines enable the production of high-tech components essential for space and aerospace applications.

The differences in technology usage within the household compared to outside the household are highlighted in the data from the text and images. According to the text, 79% of respondents use technology outside of their households, with a breakdown showing that 10% use a computer at home, 9% use it on their office computer/laptop, and 88% use it on their mobile phone [10]. In terms of radio listening habits, the image shows that 76% of respondents listen to the radio via a radio set, while 40% use a mobile phone [3]. This indicates that radio sets are more commonly used for listening to the radio within the household, whereas mobile phones are used for accessing technology outside the home.

The image also shows that there are differences in radio listening habits across different demographics. For example, males are more likely to listen to the radio via a radio set (75%) compared to females (77%), although this difference is relatively small [3]. Additionally, there are differences in listening frequency based on location and gender, with females being less likely to listen to the radio regularly compared to males [4].

Overall, the data suggests that while radio sets are more commonly used for listening to the radio within the household, mobile phones are used for accessing technology outside the home. There are also differences in radio listening habits across different demographics, with males being more likely to listen to the radio regularly compared to females.

The comparison of population distribution by caste/ethnicity, religion, and geographic location in Nepal as of September 2014 reveals distinct patterns. In terms of caste/ethnicity, the data indicates that the Chhetri caste constitutes a significant portion of the population, with a slight decrease from 16.6% to 15.3% between the initial period and September 2014. This is reflected in the table that details the distribution of different castes and ethnicities, showing how each group contributes to the overall population composition [5].

Regarding religion, the data shows a shift in the percentage of adherents across different religions. Hinduism remains the dominant religion, increasing from 81.3% to 84.9% between the initial period and September 2014. In contrast, Buddhism sees a slight decline from 9% to 8.2%, while other religions such as Islam, Christianity, Kirat, and Others show varying degrees of change, with some experiencing a decrease and others a minor increase [2].

Geographically, the distribution of the population across regions like Mountain, Hill, and Tarai shows a consistent pattern, with the Tarai region accounting for the largest share, followed by the Hill region, and then the Mountain region. The data from the map and the table indicate that the sample distribution aligns closely with the general population distribution across these regions, reflecting the natural geographical diversity of Nepal [6].

![The table shows the distribution of population percentages across different regions, along with data from September 2014 (Sep-14). The regions listed are Eastern, Central, Western, Mid-Western, and Far-Western. The percentages for the "Population (%)" and "Sep-14" columns are nearly identical for each region.](image1)

![The table displays the percentage of the population adhering to different religions over two time points. The left column indicates the percentage at an unspecified earlier time, while the right column specifies the percentage as of September 2014.](image2)

![The table displays the distribution of population percentages across three regions: Mountain, Hill, and Tarai. It comprises two columns labeled "Population (%)" and "Sep-14".](image4)

In summary, the population distribution by caste/ethnicity, religion, and geographic location in Nepal as of September 2014 shows a complex interplay of factors, with Hinduism remaining the dominant religion, the Tarai region having the largest population share, and the Chhetri caste being a significant part of the population.

The demographic composition of the population has undergone changes in both rural-urban distribution and caste/ethnicity between the initial period and September 2014. According to the data, 83% of the population was from rural areas, while 17% was from urban areas, as reflected in the table showing the percentage distribution of a population between rural and urban areas [image1]. This indicates that the majority of the population still resides in rural areas, which aligns with the national figure of 2014.

In terms of caste/ethnicity, the data shows that the distribution of different castes and ethnicities within the population has changed over time. For instance, the Chhetri caste makes up 16.6% of the population in the first measure, while it accounted for 15.3% in September 2014 [image2]. This suggests a slight decrease in the proportion of the Chhetri caste in the population. The data also indicates that these eight broad caste/ethnic groups were further collapsed into two broad categories: Non-Madhesi and Madhesi, to facilitate further comparison analysis [6].

The changes in demographic composition are also reflected in the geographic distribution of the population. The map of Nepal divided by districts and regions with color-coded samples shows that the districts are categorized into different types based on their geographical characteristics and sample representation [image3]. The map also includes labels for each district and indicates the different development regions, providing a visual representation of the population distribution across different regions.

The data on the distribution of population percentages across different regions, along with data from September 2014, shows that the percentages for the "Population (%)" and "Sep-14" columns are nearly identical for each region [image5]. This indicates that the regional distribution of the population has remained relatively stable between the initial period and September 2014.

Overall, the demographic composition of the population has shown some changes in terms of rural-urban distribution and caste/ethnicity between the initial period and September 2014, but the overall trends suggest that the majority of the population still resides in rural areas, and the distribution of different castes and ethnicities has remained relatively stable.

The mobile internet usage activities and shopping behaviors of users in Indonesia are closely intertwined, reflecting the growing reliance on mobile devices for both entertainment and commerce. According to the data, **social media** is the most common activity, accounting for **24%** of mobile internet usage, while **shopping** makes up only **8%** of activities [3]. However, this does not mean that mobile shopping is insignificant; in fact, it is a significant part of the e-commerce landscape.

![Shopping and Social Media](image3)  
*Image3 shows mobile Internet activities and download statistics, highlighting that social media is the most common activity, followed by entertainment, general info, email, games, shopping, and local search.*

In terms of shopping behavior, the data from image1 reveals that **apparel** is the most purchased item both online and offline, with **79.2%** of respondents buying apparel offline and **67.1%** online. This suggests that even though physical stores remain popular for apparel, a substantial portion of consumers are turning to online platforms for their purchases. Moreover, **social media** and **instant messaging** platforms like BB M Group, WhatsApp, and LINE are being used as primary channels for shopping, with **27%** of e-commerce users preferring to shop through IM groups [8].

The rise of mobile commerce is further supported by the fact that **almost 30% of e-commerce traffic in Asia Pacific comes from smartphones and tablets**, and in Indonesia, **almost 20% of sales on e-commerce sites come from mobile** [3]. Additionally, **mobile ads** are expected to account for **5 to 10% of total ads industry in 2015**, indicating a growing trend towards mobile-based advertising and consumer engagement.

In conclusion, the mobile internet usage activities and shopping behaviors of users in Indonesia are closely related, with social media and instant messaging playing a crucial role in driving e-commerce growth and consumer behavior.

The demographics of mobile internet users in Indonesia are closely tied to their content preferences and the business opportunities that arise from these trends. According to the data, mobile users are predominantly in the age range of 18-35 years, with a significant portion being young adults and teenagers. This age group is more likely to engage with social media, games, and entertainment content, which aligns with the high percentage of mobile users accessing social media (24%) and the popularity of games/apps as the most downloaded mobile content [image2]. 

The majority of mobile internet users are either employed full-time or are entrepreneurs, indicating a potential market for business-oriented services and products [image3]. The preference for social media and instant messaging platforms like Facebook, Line, and WhatsApp suggests a strong online community presence, which can be leveraged for marketing and customer engagement strategies.

In terms of business opportunities, the high volume of mobile traffic and the increasing reliance on mobile for shopping and information retrieval present a vast market for e-commerce, mobile advertising, and digital services. The data also shows that a significant portion of e-commerce traffic comes from smartphones and tablets, highlighting the potential for mobile-first business models [image5]. Additionally, the growth of mobile advertising, with Indonesia becoming a second-largest market for mobile ads after the US, indicates a lucrative opportunity for advertisers and media companies [5].

![Mobile Internet Usage and Download Statistics](image2)  
![Age Distribution and Occupation of Mobile Internet Users](image3)  

The demographics of mobile internet users in Indonesia, characterized by a young and active population, strongly influence their content preferences and create a robust environment for various business opportunities, particularly in e-commerce, mobile advertising, and digital services.

The comparison of streaming and album sales shares across different music genres reveals significant variations in consumption trends. According to the data, **streaming** is the dominant format, with **70%** of country music activity being streams [4], while **album sales** are more prominent in genres like rock, where **63%** of total activity is attributed to album sales [1]. This indicates that **rock is driven by catalog at all formats**, whereas **pop is mainly driven by current releases** [3].

In the bar graph (image1), **rock** has the highest percentage of streams at 82%, while **pop** has the lowest at 58%. **Country** also shows a strong stream presence at 70%. The color coding highlights that **streaming** (red) is the most significant contributor to total activity in most genres, suggesting a shift towards streaming as the leading format [4].

Additionally, image5 shows that **streaming** accounts for **70%** of total music activity, far surpassing **song sales** at 49% and **album sales** at 51%. This underscores the growing importance of streaming in music consumption.

![Streaming and Album Sales Share](image1)  
![Total Music Activity Distribution](image5)

Streaming dominates across most genres, indicating a shift towards on-demand consumption, while album sales remain significant in genres like rock. This suggests that **streaming is becoming the leading format in music consumption**, with a growing emphasis on current releases over traditional album sales.

The contribution of streams to total music activity varies significantly between genres, as shown in **image1**. For instance, **R&B/Hip-Hop** has the highest percentage of streams at 26%, while **Country** has the lowest at 12%. The system generates a response to the user's request through a series of interconnected components. First, the user input is encoded using a bidirectional LSTM utterance encoder, which converts the natural language input into a continuous vector [4]. This encoding is combined with the encoding of the previous system action to update the dialogue state via a dialogue-level LSTM [4]. The dialogue state maintains a continuous representation of the conversation, including the user's goals and tracked slots [7].

Based on this dialogue state, the model generates a probability distribution over candidate values for each tracked goal slot [7]. These values are then used to formulate a query command, which is sent to a knowledge base to retrieve requested information [5]. The results from the knowledge base are combined with the dialogue state and estimated user goals to produce a dialogue action [6].

Finally, a natural language generator (NLG) uses a template-based approach to create the final natural language response. The delexicalized tokens in the NLG template are replaced by the values from either the estimated user goal or the KB entities, depending on the emitted system action [6]. This process is illustrated in the architecture diagram, where the system components work together to generate a coherent and task-oriented response [2]. 

![Task Success Rate over Time (smoothed)](image1)  
![End-to-end task-oriented dialogue system architecture](image2)

In conclusion, the CO₂ emissions from training NLP models are comparable to or exceed those of significant everyday activities like air travel and car usage.

The impact of different positional encoding configurations and loss components on the Average Precision (AP) in the DETR-DC5 model is multifaceted, as evidenced by several key findings from the text and visual data.

![{The image shows a DETR-DC5 model analyzing animal objects in a scene, focusing on extremities for accurate classification.}](image1)

Text [7] highlights that removing spatial positional encodings leads to a significant drop in AP, while passing them only in the decoder results in a minor drop. This suggests that spatial positional encodings are crucial for maintaining high AP, especially in the encoder. Text [1] further supports this by noting that not using spatial positional encodings leads to a significant drop in AP, whereas passing them in the decoder only causes a minor drop. This indicates that spatial positional encodings are more critical in the encoder than in the decoder.

Text [3] and [8] provide visual insights into how different slots in the decoder specialize in predicting boxes of various sizes and areas. The visualization in image1 shows that the model focuses on specific parts of objects, such as legs and heads, which is essential for accurate detection. This specialization is likely influenced by the positional encodings and the loss components, which guide the model to focus on relevant areas.

Text [4] discusses the generalization ability of the DETR model, showing that it can handle unseen numbers of instances effectively. This is important for maintaining high AP even when dealing with rare classes or out-of-distribution data.

Text [9] explains the importance of each decoder layer in the DETR model, showing that AP improves significantly with each layer. This improvement is attributed to the self-attention mechanism allowing the model to inhibit duplicate predictions, which is crucial for maintaining high AP.

Text [10] presents the main results of the DETR model, showing that it outperforms existing methods in panoptic segmentation, particularly on stuff classes. This is attributed to the global reasoning allowed by the encoder attention, which is influenced by the positional encodings and loss components.

In summary, different configurations of positional encodings and loss components significantly affect the Average Precision (AP) in the DETR-DC5 model, with spatial positional encodings playing a crucial role in maintaining high AP, especially in the encoder. The model's ability to specialize in different areas and sizes of objects, as well as its generalization to unseen instances, is also influenced by these configurations.

The variation in error types and model performance across 2-hop, 3-hop, and 4-hop scenarios in the HOVER and FEVEROUS datasets can be analyzed through several key points. 

![{ProgramFC outperforms FLAN-T5 across different model sizes and hop levels}](image1)

In terms of error types, the data shows that as the complexity of the claims increases, the proportion of semantic errors in the programs also increases, with structural errors becoming particularly prevalent. For instance, in the 2-hop scenario, 71% of the programs are correct, but the majority of the errors are due to incorrect program execution. In contrast, for the 4-hop scenario, the proportion of semantic errors rises significantly, with 77% of the errors being semantic. This highlights the difficulty of generating appropriate step-by-step reasoning strategies for more complex claims ( [5] ).

![{Experimental results for different models on HOVER and FEVEROUS datasets}](image2)

Regarding model performance, the results indicate that ProgramFC consistently outperforms other models like FLAN-T5 and InstructGPT across different hop levels. On the HOVER dataset, ProgramFC outperforms the baselines by 10.38%, 11.37%, and 14.77% on two-hop, three-hop, and four-hop claims, respectively. This suggests that ProgramFC becomes increasingly effective as the required reasoning depth increases ( [10] ). 

Additionally, the error analysis reveals that while ProgramFC performs well, it still faces challenges, particularly with incorrect execution, which is a significant issue in more complex scenarios ( [6] ). 

Overall, the data indicates that as the complexity of the claims increases, both the types and frequency of errors increase, and the performance of the models also varies, with ProgramFC showing consistent superiority across different hop levels.

The 'hard-to-contrast' strategy demonstrates superior performance across various datasets, as evidenced by the results in [3] and illustrated in image1 and image5. In image1, the red line representing 'Hard-to-Contrast' consistently outperforms other methods like Random, Entropy, Margin, BALD, and Coreset across different numbers of labeled images, showing a strong correlation between AUC scores at the start and end of active learning cycles [6]. 

In image5, the 'hard-to-contrast' strategy is shown to perform best on PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, BloodMNIST, and CIFAR-10-LT. For instance, on PathMNIST, Hard-to-contrast performs best, followed by Easy-to-learn. On OrganAMNIST, Hard-to-contrast shows the highest AUC, closely followed by Easy-to-learn and Easy-to-contrast. On BloodMNIST, Hard-to-contrast is the top performer, with Easy-to-learn performing nearly as well. On CIFAR-10-LT, Hard-to-contrast leads slightly, with Easy-to-contrast and Easy-to-learn also showing strong performance.

Moreover, the 'hard-to-contrast' strategy is a label-free approach, making it practical for active learning procedures, as noted in [3]. It significantly outperforms random selection on multiple datasets, with improvements ranging from 1.8% to 24.1% on different datasets. The strategy's effectiveness is further highlighted in image3, where it is shown to select data that contributes to optimal models without relying on ground truths.

![Hard-to-Contrast Performance](image5)  
![Label Diversity Impact](image2)  

The 'hard-to-contrast' strategy not only performs better than other querying strategies but also influences the initial query selection by selecting data that leads to higher AUC scores and more effective subsequent learning cycles, as shown in image6. This makes it a strong baseline for initial query selection in image classification tasks.

The most common reasoning steps in verifying claims within the SciTAB dataset involve a variety of table-based tasks, as illustrated in **image1**. According to the breakdown provided, **simple lookup (20.6%)**, **comparison (19.5%)**, and **closed-domain knowledge (12.1%)** are the most frequent types of reasoning required. These steps reflect the need to extract information directly from the table or its context, compare numerical values, and apply domain-specific knowledge.

However, the complexity of the dataset is further highlighted in **image4**, which shows a histogram of reasoning steps. The distribution indicates that while **shallow** claims (1–2 steps) make up a smaller portion, **deep** claims (3 or more steps) are more prevalent, with 15% of claims requiring 3 steps and 20% needing 5 steps. This suggests that many claims in SciTAB demand multi-step reasoning, making them more challenging to verify.

Challenges in verifying claims also include the use of **closed-domain knowledge** and **open-domain knowledge**, as noted in **image6**. For instance, understanding terms like "Prod." in the table caption (closed-domain knowledge) or applying commonsense knowledge such as the relationship between precision and recall (open-domain knowledge) is essential. Additionally, **image9** highlights that some claims are **unverifiable** due to insufficient evidence or lack of background knowledge, with **NEI reasons** accounting for a significant portion of the dataset.

In **image2**, an example from SciTAB demonstrates how a claim can be verified through a series of reasoning steps, including the application of closed-domain knowledge, commonsense reasoning, and arithmetic operations. This example underscores the multifaceted nature of reasoning required in the dataset, as well as the potential for ambiguity and partial correctness in scientific claims.

Overall, the most common reasoning steps involve direct data extraction, comparison, and application of domain-specific knowledge, while challenges include the need for complex, multi-step reasoning and the presence of ambiguous or unverifiable claims.

The main reasoning functions in the SciTab dataset, along with their usage proportions, are detailed in the table. These functions include simple lookup (20.6%), comparison (19.5%), closed-domain knowledge (12.1%), open-domain knowledge (5.3%), commonsense knowledge (5.3%), subtract (5.3%), divide (5.3%), rank (5.3%), different / same (5.3%), add (4.0%), max / min (3.1%), col / rowname (3.1%), and trend same/different (2.9%). The distribution of these functions highlights the variety of reasoning tasks involved in the dataset.

This relationship between the reasoning functions and the complexity of reasoning steps underscores the challenging nature of the SciTab dataset, as it requires models to handle a wide range of reasoning tasks with varying degrees of difficulty.

The primary reasons for refuted and NEI claims in SCITAB are detailed in the data analysis. Refuted claims often involve incorrect calculation results (41.7%), wrong approximation words (33.3%), partially correct claims (10.0%), mismatched values (8.3%), and incorrect operation types (6.7%) [image4]. NEI claims are primarily due to a lack of sufficient evidence (33.3%), absence of open-domain knowledge (25.0%), lack of closed-domain knowledge (15.0%), references to other tables (11.7%), vague pronouns (8.3%), and omission of specific information (6.7%) [image4].

These reasons significantly impact the performance of different models in zero-shot 3-class classification. As shown in the confusion matrices, InstructGPT frequently misclassifies supported and refuted claims as 'NEI' (26.8% for Supported and 23.6% for Refuted) [image2], while GPT-4 overconfidently categorizes NEI claims as either supported or refuted [image2]. This highlights the difficulty models face in accurately distinguishing between refuted and NEI claims, which is a key challenge for SCITAB. The inclusion of the NEI class tends to diminish models' confidence, causing a shift in their predictions from 'supported/refuted' to 'NEI' [text10].

The performance of InstructGPT and GPT-4 on the zero-shot 3-class classification task, as shown in ![Confusion matrices for InstructGPT and GPT-4](image3), reveals distinct patterns. InstructGPT frequently misclassifies claims, with a high rate of predicting NEI (Not Enough Information) for both Supported and Refuted categories, indicating uncertainty or lack of sufficient evidence. Conversely, GPT-4 shows overconfidence, often incorrectly categorizing NEI claims as either Supported or Refuted. This discrepancy highlights the challenge of accurately determining verifiability in scientific fact-checking tasks.

![Error types and their proportions](image4) provides insight into the types of errors contributing to these performance differences. Grounding errors, which account for 50% of errors, involve incorrect associations of data with table cells, a significant challenge for both models. Ambiguity errors (22%) and calculation errors (20%) also play critical roles, with ambiguity particularly highlighting the difficulty in handling vague or unclear scientific claims. Program errors (8%), while less common, underscore issues with correctly executing reasoning steps, especially in complex numerical tasks.

These findings emphasize the unique challenges posed by the SCITAB dataset, where accurate table grounding and handling of ambiguous claims are crucial for effective scientific fact-checking. The analysis underscores the need for further research and development in addressing these specific challenges.

The performance and error types of InstructGPT and GPT-4 in zero-shot 3-class classification tasks reveal distinct patterns. InstructGPT tends to be less confident, frequently misclassifying supported and refuted claims as 'NEI' (Not Enough Information), as shown in the confusion matrix ![Confusion matrices for InstructGPT and GPT-4 in zero-shot 3-class setting](image2). In contrast, GPT-4 exhibits overconfidence, incorrectly categorizing NEI claims as either supported or refuted. This highlights a key challenge in the SCI T AB dataset: distinguishing whether a claim is verifiable.

The error types in the zero-shot 3-class setting, as detailed in Table 5 ![Error types and their estimated proportions for incorrectly-predicted samples in PoT](image1), show that InstructGPT's errors are more aligned with the NEI class, while GPT-4's errors are more distributed across all classes. This suggests that InstructGPT struggles with the ambiguity and lack of sufficient information in NEI claims, whereas GPT-4 overestimates its ability to verify claims, leading to incorrect classifications.

These differences indicate that InstructGPT has lower accuracy in handling complex and ambiguous scientific claims, particularly those requiring nuanced understanding of evidence and context. GPT-4, while more confident, also faces challenges in accurately determining the verifiability of claims, suggesting that both models have limitations in the specific context of the SCI T AB dataset.

The main challenges faced by InstructGPT and GPT-4 in accurately classifying NEI claims in the zero-shot 3-class classification task are primarily related to the difficulty of distinguishing between verifiable and unverifiable claims, as well as the inherent complexity of scientific reasoning. 

![The table lists types of errors and their estimated proportions in percentages: Grounding errors: 50%, Ambiguity errors: 22%, Calculation errors: 20%, Program errors: 8%](image1)

InstructGPT struggles with accurately predicting the NEI class, often classifying supported and refuted claims as 'NEI' due to a lack of confidence. This is highlighted in the confusion matrix where InstructGPT has a high percentage of predictions for NEI across all classes [5]. On the other hand, GPT-4 exhibits overconfidence, incorrectly categorizing NEI claims as either supported or refuted [5]. 

These challenges differ significantly between the two models. InstructGPT's approach is characterized by a "less confident" pattern, while GPT-4 shows an "over confident" tendency. The differences in their handling of NEI claims can be attributed to their underlying architectures and training data, which influence their ability to generalize and reason about complex scientific claims.

The safety performance of Llama 2-Chat models is generally comparable or lower than other models, as shown in the violation percentage comparisons. For instance, in Figure 17, Llama 2-Chat has comparable or lower overall violation percentages across model sizes, while ChatGPT and Falcon come next, followed by MPT and Vicuna [3]. ![Violation Percentage](image3) However, it is important to interpret these results carefully due to limitations in the prompt set and subjectivity in the review guidelines [3].

![Human Evaluation Results](image2) The bar chart in image2 shows that Llama 2-Chat models perform well relative to other models across different scenarios, with win rates indicating their superiority in helpfulness and safety. The chart also highlights that Falcon performs particularly well on single-turn conversations but much worse on multi-turn conversations, which could be due to its lack of multi-turn supervised fine-tuning data [7].

The training processes that contribute to the safety features of Llama 2-Chat include pretraining, supervised fine-tuning, human feedback, and reinforcement learning with human feedback (RLHF). The flowchart in image1 depicts the training process, starting with pretraining data and involving self-supervised learning to develop Llama 2. Supervised fine-tuning is then used to create an initial version of Llama 2-Chat. Human preference data is utilized to develop safety and helpfulness reward models, and RLHF techniques like rejection sampling and proximal policy optimization (PPO) are employed for iterative refinement [1]. 

These processes ensure that Llama 2-Chat models are optimized for dialogue use cases and have enhanced safety features, making them a suitable substitute for closed-source models based on human evaluations [8].

The removal of knowledge elements significantly impacts the performance metrics in the context of 'Conscious Incompetence' and retrieval analysis. As shown in image3, when more knowledge is removed, precision (blue line) increases substantially, indicating that the model becomes better at identifying and focusing on the remaining knowledge. However, recall (orange line) remains relatively stable, suggesting that the model's ability to retrieve all relevant information is not greatly affected by the removal of knowledge elements. The F1-Score (green line) shows a moderate increase, reflecting a balance between precision and recall.

These changes imply that models can filter out incorrect information to some extent, which is beneficial for precision but does not significantly affect recall since the model can still identify the correct information when it is present. The stability of recall suggests that the model has some capability to recognize and cite the correct information even when parts of the knowledge are missing. This indicates that models can handle absent knowledge to a limited extent, but there is a clear trade-off between the explicitness of the question context and the irrelevance of the knowledge required by the question. ![Recall Stability](image3) 

The implications of these changes highlight the importance of retrieval accuracy in generating high-quality attributed texts, as noted in text3. When retrieval accuracy is reasonably high, the correctness of citations is not the most significant concern compared to recall, as indicated in text7. This suggests that models can effectively manage the challenge of absent knowledge when the retrieval process is accurate.

The use of logical constraints and demonstration samples significantly impacts the performance of different models on the MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets. According to [3], adding relevant logic improves model performance, while irrelevant logic causes fluctuations. This is illustrated in **image1**, which shows that models like GPT-4 and Vicuna achieve higher Micro-F1 scores when logical constraints are applied, especially on the MAVEN-ERE task. 

**Image4** further demonstrates this effect, showing that as the number of demonstration samples increases, the Micro-F1 scores for both MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank improve, particularly when logical constraints are incorporated. For instance, the performance of Llama-2-13B with logical constraints surpasses that of models without logical constraints even with fewer demonstrations. 

Additionally, **image2** provides a case study where pre-training (PT) with logical constraints leads to significant improvements in model accuracy, as seen in the corrected answers provided by Llama-2-13B-PT compared to the original model. 

In summary, incorporating logical constraints and increasing the number of demonstration samples generally enhances model performance on these datasets, though the exact impact varies depending on the model and the specific conditions under which they are tested.

![{The table compares model performance on MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank with different conditions including logical constraints, retrieved constraints, and post-processing.}](image1)

From the table, we can see that models like Turbo, Davinci, GPT-4, Vicuna, and Llama2 show significant improvements in Micro-F1 and a reduction in Logical Inconsistency (LI) when using logical constraints or post-processing. For instance, under all logical constraints, the LI percentages are 0% for both datasets, indicating perfect consistency [1].

![{This image shows a case study of Llama-2-13B before and after pre-training, highlighting the improvement in event relation extraction.}](image2)

The case study demonstrates that pre-training with logical constraints significantly improves the model's ability to correctly identify and relate events, as seen in the corrected answers marked with a '✓' after pre-training [2].

![{The table presents the performance of Vicuna-13B-PT and Llama2-13B-PT on MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank with various configurations.}](image3)

For Vicuna-13B-PT, the best Micro-F1 on MAVEN-ERE is 18.0% with CoT and logical constraints, while the lowest LI is 0% with post-processing. On Causal-TimeBank, the best Micro-F1 is 12.1% under all logical constraints, and the lowest LI is 0% with post-processing. For Llama2-13B-PT, the highest Micro-F1 on MAVEN-ERE is 26.4% with CoT and logical constraints, and the lowest LI is 0% with post-processing [3].

![{The table evaluates different models on three tasks, showing Micro-F1 and LI scores for various configurations.}](image4)

RoBERTa-Large, Turbo, Davinci, GPT-4, Vicuna, and Llama2 are evaluated in various configurations, with the highest scores for each task and model variation bolded. This indicates that logical constraints and post-processing significantly enhance performance across different models [4].

![{The graphs show the impact of demonstration samples and iterations on performance and logical inconsistency.}](image5)

The left graph shows that increasing the number of demonstration samples improves performance, while the right graph illustrates that logical inconsistency decreases with more iterations, highlighting the effectiveness of iterative retrieval and logical constraints [5].

In summary, logical constraints and post-processing both contribute to reducing logical inconsistency in LLM models on MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets, with post-processing achieving zero logical inconsistency in some cases [6].

The distribution of difficulty levels in the MMMU dataset is as follows: **Easy (28%)**, **Medium (45%)**, and **Hard (27%)** [5]. This distribution ensures a balanced challenge across different skill levels, reflecting the diverse nature of the disciplines covered. The dataset spans six broad disciplines—Art & Design, Business, Science, Health & Medicine, Humanities & Social Sciences, and Tech & Engineering—each with 30 subjects and 183 subfields [8]. 

![The distribution of 11.5K multimodal questions across six broad disciplines, 30 subjects, and 183 subfields.](image2)

The difficulty levels are carefully curated to test expert-level reasoning, as many problems require applying advanced domain-specific knowledge to derive solutions. For instance, questions in the Science discipline may involve complex mathematical reasoning, while those in Health & Medicine might require interpreting medical images and understanding clinical findings [3]. The inclusion of interleaved text and image inputs further challenges models to integrate visual and textual information for accurate reasoning [8].

The MMMU benchmark is designed to evaluate not only the breadth of knowledge but also the depth of reasoning required across various disciplines, making it a comprehensive tool for assessing the capabilities of large multimodal models [9].

The distribution of subject areas in the MMMU dataset is closely aligned with its intended coverage of depth and breadth in reasoning and knowledge. As highlighted in **image1**, the dataset includes 11.5K college-level problems across six broad disciplines: Engineering (26%), Art & Design (11%), Business (14%), Science (23%), Humanities & Social Sciences (9%), and Medicine (17%). This comprehensive coverage ensures a **breadth** of knowledge, as the dataset spans 30 subjects and 183 subfields, reflecting a wide range of academic disciplines.

In terms of **depth**, the dataset is designed to test expert-level skills, requiring not only visual perception but also domain-specific knowledge and intricate reasoning. For instance, questions in the Science category may involve applying concepts like "Fourier Transform" or "Equilibrium Theory," while those in Health & Medicine require understanding complex medical imaging techniques such as MRI scans. The **image1** also highlights that the dataset features interleaved text-image inputs, which demand models to jointly understand both the images and text, often requiring deep subject knowledge and complex reasoning.

Furthermore, **image4** provides a detailed breakdown of the distribution of questions across disciplines, showing that each category includes subfields with associated percentages indicating the portion of questions related to each subject or discipline. This structure supports the **depth** goal by ensuring that models are challenged with tasks that require nuanced understanding and application of knowledge within specific domains.

In summary, the distribution of subject areas in the MMMU dataset is carefully designed to reflect both the **breadth** of knowledge across multiple disciplines and the **depth** of reasoning and subject-specific expertise required to solve the tasks.

Regarding image usage, MMMU features a diverse array of image types, from diagrams and tables to photographs, chemical structures, and medical images, as noted in image1 [1]. This diversity is further emphasized in image7, which shows the distribution of different image types within the 11.5K questions [7].

The question formats in MMMU are predominantly multiple-choice, with a high percentage of questions containing images, as detailed in image3 [3]. This format ensures that models must not only perceive and understand information across different modalities but also apply reasoning with subject-specific knowledge to derive the solution [6].

The MMMU benchmark is unique in its comprehensive coverage of subjects, requirement for expert-level reasoning, and diverse image usage, making it a significant advancement in the assessment of LMMs.

The MMMU benchmark stands out from other benchmarks in terms of reasoning depth, knowledge breadth, and the variety of image types used. In terms of **reasoning depth**, MMMU requires models to perform **expert-level reasoning** with **subject-specific knowledge**, such as applying "Fourier Transform" or "Equilibrium Theory" to derive solutions, which is not commonly found in other benchmarks [5]. This is further emphasized in image4, which highlights that MMMU tests **expert-level visual perception and reasoning** [4].

Regarding **knowledge breadth**, MMMU covers **30 different subjects** and **183 subfields**, spanning disciplines like Art & Design, Business, Science, Health & Medicine, Humanities & Social Science, and Tech & Engineering [5]. This is contrasted with prior benchmarks that are heavily focused on **daily knowledge and common sense** [9], indicating a significant difference in the **breadth** of knowledge covered.

In terms of **image variety**, MMMU includes **30 different image formats**, ranging from **visual scenes like photographs and paintings** to **diagrams, tables, charts, chemical structures, medical images, and more** [5]. This is highlighted in image2, which shows that MMMU has a **broad range of image types** compared to other benchmarks like VQA, GQA, VisWiz, and others [2].

![{MMMU benchmark excels in depth, breadth, and image variety compared to other benchmarks}](image2)

The evaluation frameworks that focus on both retrieval and generation quality include RGB, RAGAS, ARES, and TruLens. These frameworks assess various aspects such as context relevance, faithfulness, answer relevance, noise robustness, negation rejection, information integration, and counterfactual robustness. The metrics used vary but commonly include accuracy, EM (Exact Match), recall, precision, cosine similarity, BLEU, ROUGE-L, and BertScore. ![Context Relevance](image5)

The key evaluation aspects for assessing RAG's retrieval and generation quality include **retrieval quality**, **generation quality**, **answer relevance**, **noise robustness**, **negative rejection**, **information integration**, **faithfulness**, and **counterfactual robustness**. These aspects are crucial for understanding how well RAG systems perform in different scenarios. 

![Context Relevance, Faithfulness, Answer Relevance, Noise Robustness, Negative Rejection, Information Integration, Counterfactual Robustness](image3)

Each of these aspects is evaluated using specific metrics. For instance, **context relevance** is assessed using metrics like Accuracy, EM, Recall, Precision, Cosine Similarity, Hit Rate, MRR, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L. **Faithfulness** is measured by Accuracy, EM, BLEU, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L. **Answer relevance** is evaluated through Accuracy, EM, and R-Rate. **Noise robustness** is assessed with Accuracy, Recall, and Precision. **Negative rejection** uses Accuracy and EM. **Information integration** is measured by Accuracy, MRR, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L. **Counterfactual robustness** is evaluated by Accuracy and ROUGE/ROUGE-L.

Different evaluation frameworks focus on these aspects differently. For example, the **RGB†** framework targets retrieval and generation quality, focusing on noise robustness, negative rejection, information integration, and counterfactual robustness. The **RECALL†** framework focuses on generation quality with an emphasis on counterfactual robustness. **RAGAS‡**, **ARES‡**, and **TruLens‡** all target retrieval and generation quality but emphasize context relevance, faithfulness, and answer relevance. The **CRUD†** framework targets a broader range of aspects including creative generation, knowledge-intensive QA, error correction, and summarization.

These differences highlight the varied approaches to evaluating RAG systems, each tailored to specific goals and challenges in the field.

The RGB and CRUD evaluation frameworks both focus on assessing the performance of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) models, but they differ in their targets and aspects of evaluation. 

![Evaluation of RAG](image4) ![Key Issues of RAG](image1)

RGB emphasizes **retrieval quality** and **generation quality**, with specific aspects including **noise robustness**, **negative rejection**, **information integration**, and **counterfactual robustness**. It uses metrics such as **Accuracy**, **EM (Exact Match)**, and **ROUGE/ROUGE-L** to evaluate these aspects [4]. 

In contrast, CRUD focuses on **retrieval quality** and **generation quality** as well, but its aspects include **creative generation**, **knowledge-intensive QA**, **error correction**, and **summarization**. The metrics used for CRUD include **BLEU**, **ROUGE-L**, **BertScore**, and **RAGQuestEval** [4]. 

The key difference lies in the specific aspects they evaluate and the metrics used to assess them. RGB is more focused on the robustness and reliability of the model's outputs, while CRUD is geared towards evaluating the model's ability to handle a variety of generation tasks and correct errors.

The evaluation frameworks RGB, RAGAS, and CRUD differ in their evaluation targets, aspects, and quantitative metrics as illustrated in the table. 

![RAG Evaluation Frameworks](image4)

RGB focuses on **Retrieval Quality** and **Generation Quality**, with aspects like **Noise Robustness**, **Negative Rejection**, **Information Integration**, and **Counterfactual Robustness**. It uses metrics such as **Accuracy**, **EM (Exact Match)**, and **R-Rate (Reappearance Rate)** [4]. 

RAGAS targets **Retrieval Quality** and **Generation Quality**, emphasizing **Context Relevance**, **Faithfulness**, and **Answer Relevance**. Its metrics include **Cosine Similarity** and **Accuracy** [4]. 

CRUD evaluates **Retrieval Quality** and **Generation Quality**, covering **Creative Generation**, **Knowledge-intensive QA**, **Error Correction**, and **Summarization**. It employs metrics like **BLEU**, **ROUGE-L**, **BertScore**, and **RAGQuestEval** [4]. 

Each framework is designed to assess different facets of RAG performance, reflecting the diverse challenges and requirements in evaluating retrieval-augmented generation systems.

Advanced RAG improves upon Naive RAG by introducing pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies to enhance retrieval quality. It refines indexing techniques through a sliding window approach, fine-grained segmentation, and metadata incorporation, along with optimization methods to streamline the retrieval process [1]. This is illustrated in the technology tree diagram, which shows the evolution of RAG from pre-training to inference, highlighting key advancements like those in Advanced RAG [image1]. 

![Modular RAG Evolution](image1)

The Modular RAG plays a crucial role in enhancing retrieval-augmented generation by introducing specialized components such as the Search, Fusion, Memory, Routing, Predict, and Task Adapter modules. These modules improve the system's adaptability and versatility, allowing for more dynamic interactions and better handling of diverse tasks [6]. The comparison of RAG paradigms shows that Modular RAG offers greater flexibility by incorporating various functional modules and processes [image3].

![RAG Paradigm Comparison](image3)

The Naive, Advanced, and Modular RAG frameworks differ significantly in their approach to handling document retrieval and query processing. The **Naive RAG** follows a traditional "Retrieve-Read" framework, involving indexing, retrieval, and generation [3]. It is straightforward but has limitations in retrieval quality and adaptability.

![Modular RAG flexibility](image5)  
![Naive RAG process](image1)  
![Advanced RAG enhancements](image1)

The **Advanced RAG** improves upon Naive RAG by incorporating optimization strategies in both pre-retrieval and post-retrieval stages. It uses techniques like query routing, rewriting, expansion, reranking, summarization, and fusion to enhance performance [1]. This framework addresses some of the limitations of Naive RAG through refined indexing techniques and optimization methods [8].

The **Modular RAG** offers greater flexibility by introducing various specific functional modules. It allows for module substitution or reconfiguration to address specific challenges, going beyond the fixed structures of Naive and Advanced RAG [5]. Modules such as Search, RAG-Fusion, Memory, Routing, Predict, and Task Adapter enable more dynamic interactions and adaptability across different tasks [7]. This modular approach supports both sequential processing and integrated end-to-end training, making it highly versatile [10].

In summary, while Naive RAG is simple and direct, Advanced RAG introduces optimizations for better performance, and Modular RAG provides the highest level of flexibility and adaptability through specialized modules.

The collapsed tree retrieval method demonstrates superior performance compared to tree traversal and RAPTOR with DPR on the QASPER dataset. As shown in **image3**, the collapsed tree method achieves its peak F1 score at 2000 tokens, which is the optimal context length for the QASPER dataset. This method consistently outperforms the tree traversal approach, which shows a steady increase in F1 score but lags behind the collapsed tree in overall performance.

In terms of specific performance metrics, **image4** illustrates that the SBERT with RAPTOR combination achieves an Answer F1 score of 36.70 on the QASPER dataset, which is higher than the scores for BM25 with RAPTOR (27.00) and DPR with RAPTOR (32.23). Additionally, the Accuracy (QuALITY) for SBERT with RAPTOR is 56.6%, surpassing the other models.

Furthermore, **image5** provides a broader comparison across various metrics such as ROUGE, BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR. Models enhanced with RAPTOR generally show improved performance across these metrics compared to those without it, indicating that the RAPTOR augmentation significantly enhances retrieval effectiveness.

Overall, the collapsed tree retrieval method, when used with RAPTOR, offers better flexibility and performance on the QASPER dataset and other evaluation metrics compared to tree traversal and RAPTOR with DPR.

RAPTOR employs two querying mechanisms: tree traversal and collapsed tree. The **collapsed tree** method is more flexible and performs better, as shown in **image3**, where it peaks at 2000 tokens with the best F1 score, slightly decreasing as the context length increases to 2500. In contrast, the **tree traversal** method shows a steady increase in F1 score with context length but overall performs lower than the collapsed tree method. This suggests that the collapsed tree approach is more effective for retrieving information at the correct level of granularity for a given question.

![Collapsed tree and Tree Traversal Performance](image3)

In terms of performance across different models and metrics, **image5** provides a detailed comparison. Models enhanced with RAPTOR generally yield better performance across ROUGE, BLEU, and METEOR metrics compared to those without it. For instance, **SBERT with RAPTOR** achieves ROUGE: 30.87%, BLEU-1: 23.50%, BLEU-4: 6.42%, and METEOR: 19.20%, which are higher than the corresponding values for SBERT without RAPTOR. Similarly, **DPR with RAPTOR** shows improved performance in all metrics compared to DPR without RAPTOR.

The **collapsed tree** approach, as described in **image1**, demonstrates superior performance on the QASPER dataset, with RAPTOR achieving the highest F-1 Match scores across different models (GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA). Specifically, RAPTOR's F-1 scores are at least 1.8% higher than DPR and 5.3% higher than BM25 for all tested language models.

In summary, the **collapsed tree** method outperforms the **tree traversal** method in terms of performance across different context lengths, and RAPTOR's performance with various models is significantly better in metrics like ROUGE, BLEU, and METEOR when augmented with the RAPTOR component.

The RAPTOR model demonstrates superior performance across various evaluation metrics when used with different retrieval methods. As shown in **image1**, RAPTOR outperforms BM25 and DPR in both GPT-3 and UnifiedQA accuracy, with scores of 62.4% and 56.6% respectively, compared to 57.3% and 49.9% for BM25 and 60.4% and 53.9% for DPR. This is further supported by **image4**, which reveals that RAPTOR achieves the highest F-1 Match scores across all models: 53.1% with GPT-3, 55.7% with GPT-4, and 36.6% with UnifiedQA.

In terms of specific metrics, **image3** illustrates that models enhanced with RAPTOR generally yield better performance across ROUGE, BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR scores compared to those without RAPTOR. For instance, SBERT with RAPTOR achieves a METEOR score of 19.20%, surpassing SBERT without RAPTOR's 18.15%.

Regarding the impact of context length on the tree traversal and collapsed tree methods, **image2** provides a graph comparing these methods based on F1 score. The green line representing the collapsed tree method peaks at 2000 tokens with the best F1 score, slightly decreasing as the context length increases to 2500. In contrast, the blue line for tree traversal shows a steady increase in F1 score with context length but overall performs lower than the collapsed tree method. This suggests that the collapsed tree approach with 2000 tokens is optimal for the QASPER dataset, as noted in **text quote [6]**.

RAPTOR demonstrates superior performance compared to traditional retrieval methods like BM25 and DPR across multiple metrics and datasets. As shown in Table 6, RAPTOR outperforms BM25 and DPR in ROUGE-L, BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR metrics, with margins ranging from 1.7 to 5.8 points in some cases [2]. ![RAPTOR Performance Comparison](image3) 

On the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR achieves higher F-1 Match scores than BM25 and DPR when using GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA 3B, with scores of 53.1%, 55.7%, and 36.6% respectively [3]. ![F-1 Match Scores](image5)

In the QuAL-ITY dev dataset, RAPTOR outperforms BM25 and DPR by at least 2.0% in accuracy [10]. ![Accuracy Comparison](image1)

The hierarchical structure of RAPTOR allows it to select nodes from different layers of the tree, which often results in more relevant and comprehensive information for downstream tasks compared to DPR [7]. ![RAPTOR Querying Process](image4)

Overall, RAPTOR consistently outperforms traditional retrieval methods across various metrics and datasets, demonstrating its effectiveness in question-answering tasks [4].

RAPTOR outperforms other retrieval methods across different evaluation metrics and datasets due to its advanced querying structure, which allows for more effective information synthesis. As shown in Table 6, RAPTOR surpasses BM25 and DPR by 7.3 and 2.7 points in ROUGE-L, respectively, and outperforms them in BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR by margins ranging from 1.7 to 5.8 and 0.7 to 2.1 points, respectively [1]. In the QuAL-ITY dev dataset, RAPTOR outperforms BM25 and DPR by at least 2.0% in accuracy [2]. 

The querying structure of RAPTOR plays a crucial role in its performance. By examining the contribution of each layer of nodes, it is hypothesized that upper nodes play a crucial role in handling thematic or multi-hop queries requiring a broader understanding of the text [3]. This is further supported by image1, which shows the performance of different layers under various conditions, with Layer 2 showing a significant value of 73.68 when using 3 layers [image1].

The safety evaluations show that models with larger parameters (34B) generally have higher safety scores across both the "Crowdsourced" and "Red Team" datasets. For the "Crowdsourced" dataset, 7B parameter models had 99.2% safe responses, while 34B models had 99.7% safe responses. On the "Red Team" dataset, 34B models showed 93.9% safe responses, indicating a consistent trend of higher safety with larger models [3].

Regarding the level of agreement among annotators in model comparisons involving Chameleon, the table indicates that in most comparisons, there is a significant level of agreement. For instance, when comparing Chameleon to Gemini+, 31.5% of instances had all three annotators agreeing, 58.1% had two annotators agreeing, and 10.3% had no agreement. Similar patterns are observed in comparisons with GPT-4V+ and other models, showing a high degree of consistency in annotator judgments [1].

The multimodal retriever system processes and ranks objects for recognition in detection datasets through a series of steps that combine image and text data. First, the system uses a visual encoder to process the input image and generate an image embedding, as described in [10]. This embedding is then navigated through a previously constructed memory index to identify the top-k related images based on similarity. The retrieved categories are then used as a preliminary filter to narrow down the vast possibilities to those most likely relevant, based on historical data and the semantic closeness of stored labels to the image content [10].

In the context of object detection datasets, the system employs additional pre-processing steps such as cropping and blurring to help the MLLMs understand the objects of interest. As shown in image4, the image is first cropped based on proposal bounding box coordinates and resized to a fixed proportion. Non-target areas surrounding the objects of interest are blurred to direct the MLLMs' focus toward the relevant objects, facilitating their identification in object detection tasks [8].

Once the image embeddings are processed and the relevant objects are identified, the system retrieves the top-k category names from the memory, as detailed in [4]. These retrieved class names are then passed to the MLLMs, which use their advanced linguistic and semantic analysis capabilities to rank these class names based on contextual appropriateness with the input image. This ranking process is crucial for achieving accurate and contextually aware classification predictions, as illustrated in image1 and image2.

The integration of the multimodal retriever with the MLLMs allows the system to leverage the strengths of both approaches, enhancing the few-shot/zero-shot recognition abilities for datasets characterized by extensive and fine-grained vocabularies. This combination not only addresses the inherent limitations in fine-grained recognition but also preserves the model’s comprehensive knowledge base, significantly boosting accuracy across a range of vision-language recognition tasks [2].

The error analysis results for Step-Back + RAG differ between TimeQA and StrategyQA in terms of the percentage of errors corrected and introduced. On TimeQA, Step-Back + RAG fixes 39.9% of the predictions where the baseline prediction is wrong, while causing 5.6% errors. Additionally, it fixes 21.6% of errors coming from RAG, with only 6.3% of errors introduced by Step-Back to RAG. In contrast, on StrategyQA, Step-Back + RAG turns 15.4% of wrong predictions into correct ones, leading to 6.1% errors, and fixes 12.7% of errors from RAG, with 4.4% errors introduced by Step-Back. These differences highlight the varying difficulty levels of the tasks and the effectiveness of Step-Back in different contexts.

This image compares the error rates between TimeQA and StrategyQA, showing the percentage of correct and incorrect predictions for both datasets.  

The significance of these differences lies in the nature of the tasks and the dataset examples. TimeQA involves temporal reasoning, which may require more precise information retrieval, while StrategyQA focuses on strategic thinking and multi-step reasoning. The higher error correction rate in TimeQA suggests that Step-Back is effective in improving retrieval accuracy, whereas in StrategyQA, the error correction is less pronounced, reflecting the complexity of strategic reasoning tasks.

The performance of SPECTER in document classification and citation prediction is significantly better than other models. According to [5], SPECTER achieves an 86.4 F1 score on the MeSH dataset, which is an improvement of about 2.3 points over the best baseline. In citation prediction, SPECTER outperforms Citeomatic by 2.7 and 4.0 points on co-view and co-read tasks respectively. Additionally, SPECTER achieves a nDCG of 94.8 on co-citation tasks, improving over SGC by 2.3 points. ![SPECTER vs SciBERT Performance](image1) 

In terms of topic clustering, SPECTER produces more compact clusters compared to SciBERT. This is evident in [6], where the homogeneity and completeness values for SPECTER are 0.41 and 0.72, respectively, compared to SciBERT's 0.19 and 0.63. The visual differences in topic clustering between SPECTER and SciBERT are shown in [image2], where SPECTER's clustering pattern indicates better separation of academic disciplines.

The SPECTER model demonstrates superior performance compared to other models across various tasks, as shown in the table. For instance, on the classification task, SPECTER achieves the highest scores across most metrics, with an average of 80.0, which is a 3.1 point absolute improvement over the next-best baseline [1]. In user activity prediction, SPECTER achieves a MAP score of 83.8 on the co-view task and 84.5 on co-read, improving over the best baseline (Citeomatic) by 2.7 and 4.0 points, respectively [6]. On citation prediction, SPECTER outperforms Citeomatic on co-citations by 2.0 nDCG [6]. For the recommendation task, SPECTER achieves an nDCG of 53.9, outperforming all other models [7].

Including additional metadata such as venue slightly decreases performance, except on document classification (which makes sense, as we would expect venues to have high correlation with paper topics). Adding authors as an input (along with title and abstract) hurts performance. One possible explanation is that author names are sparse in the corpus, making it difficult for the model to infer document-level relatedness from them. As another possible reason of this behavior, tokenization using Wordpieces might be suboptimal for author names. Many author names are out-of-vocabulary for SciBERT and thus, they might be split into sub-words and shared across names that are not semantically related, leading to noisy correlation [3].

We used citations to build triplets for our loss function, however there are other metrics that have good support from the bibliometrics literature (Klavans and Boyack , 2006 ) that warrant exploring as a way to create relatedness graphs. Including other information such as outgoing citations as additional input to the model would be yet another area to explore in future.

The enhancements to BERT-MRC models show varying degrees of F1-score improvements across different datasets. On the Chinese MSRA and OntoNotes 4.0 datasets, the BERT-MRC+DSC model also demonstrates significant improvements, with the highest F1-scores in both datasets, as indicated in ![BERT-MRC+DSC performance on Chinese datasets](image2). In the MRC task, the proposed DSC loss obtains significant performance boost on both EM and F1 scores, outperforming XLNet by +1.25 in terms of F1 score on SQuADv1.1 and achieving 87.65 on EM and 89.51 on F1 on SQuAD v2.0, as shown in ![Performance of DSC on MRC tasks](image3). The consistent performance of DSC across all datasets highlights its effectiveness in improving F1-scores for BERT-MRC models.

For the CoNLL 2003 dataset, **BERT-MRC+DSC** achieves the highest F1 score of 93.33, outperforming **BERT-MRC+DL** (93.17) and **BERT-MRC+FL** (93.11) by +0.29 in F1 score [9]. This improvement is consistent with the general trend where DSC enhances performance on imbalanced datasets [8].

The comparison between COMET-RANK and BLEU metrics in evaluating translation quality reveals distinct trends across different language pairs. According to the data presented in the table, COMET-RANK generally outperforms BLEU in terms of correlation with human judgments. For instance, in the language pair "en-cs," COMET-RANK achieves a score of 0.711 when using reference translations, whereas BLEU scores are not explicitly mentioned but are known to be lower in such contexts [9]. The inclusion of references significantly improves the COMET-RANK score, as indicated by the Δτ values, which show the difference between scores with and without references [1].

![The table presents the results of a translation performance metric called COMET-RANK for various language pairs. The first row lists the language pairs, using ISO language codes; for example, "en-cs" refers to English to Czech, and "cs-en" refers to Czech to English. The metrics are evaluated in two scenarios: using only reference translations (COMET-RANK (ref. only)) and using the COMET-RANK metric more generally. The values in this table represent scores that likely indicate the quality of translation, with higher values suggesting better performance.](image1)

In contrast, BLEU is a traditional n-gram matching metric that often fails to capture semantic similarity beyond the lexical level [1]. This limitation is evident in its lower performance compared to COMET-RANK, especially in language pairs where English is the target, as noted in the results [2]. The graphs further illustrate that COMET metrics, including COMET-RANK, tend to perform better than BLEU across different sets of systems, with higher Kendall Tau values indicating stronger correlation with human judgments [2].

![The image contains five line graphs, each representing the performance of different machine translation (MT) evaluation metrics over various top MT systems translated into English from different languages. The graphs are titled based on language pairs: de-en (German to English), fi-en (Finnish to English), lt-en (Lithuanian to English), ru-en (Russian to English), and zh-en (Chinese to English).](image2)

Overall, COMET-RANK demonstrates superior performance in capturing translation quality, particularly when reference translations are included, while BLEU remains a traditional metric with limitations in semantic understanding.
